The '''2015 Greek football scandal''' emerged on 6 April 2015 when prosecutor Aristidis Korreas' 173-page work was revealed. [[Telephone tapping]] operated by the [[National Intelligence Service (Greece)|National Intelligence Service of Greece]] since 2011 has played a significant role in the case.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://directnews.gr/athletics/60110-olo-to-porisma-tou-eisaggelea-ar-korea-gia-ta-sthmena-sto-podosfairo-protagonistikos-o-rolos-tou-vaggelh-marinakh-eggrafa.html | script-title = el:Πόρισμα εισαγγελέα Αριστείδη Κορρέα για την ύπαρξη εγκληματικής οργάνωσης στο ποδόσφαιρο | page = 12 | language = Greek | publisher = Public Prosecutor's Office of District Court Judges | date = 3 December 2014 | accessdate = 6 April 2015 | title = Archived copy | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150410102133/http://directnews.gr/athletics/60110-olo-to-porisma-tou-eisaggelea-ar-korea-gia-ta-sthmena-sto-podosfairo-protagonistikos-o-rolos-tou-vaggelh-marinakh-eggrafa.html | archive-date = 10 April 2015 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref> According to the prosecutor's conclusion, [[Olympiakos F.C.]] owner [[Evangelos Marinakis]] along with [[Hellenic Football Federation|Greek Football Federation]] members Theodoros Kouridis, and Georgios Sarris are suspected of directing a criminal organization since 2011. The goal behind their scheme was to "absolutely control Greek football's fate by the methods of blackmailing and fraud",<ref>{{cite web | url = http://europe.newsweek.com/greece-charges-41-over-match-fixing-football-scandal-deepens-327763 | title=Greece charges 41 over match-fixing as football scandal deepens | publisher = europe.newsweek.com | date = 27 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://directnews.gr/athletics/60110-olo-to-porisma-tou-eisaggelea-ar-korea-gia-ta-sthmena-sto-podosfairo-protagonistikos-o-rolos-tou-vaggelh-marinakh-eggrafa.html | script-title = el:Πόρισμα εισαγγελέα Αριστείδη Κορρέα για την ύπαρξη εγκληματικής οργάνωσης στο ποδόσφαιρο | page = 159 | language = Greek | publisher = Public Prosecutor's Office of District Court Judges | date = 3 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/dec/04/sixteen-charged-greek-football-match-fixing-investigation|title=Sixteen reportedly charged in Greek football match-fixing Battlefield|work=International Policy Digest|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sdna.gr/gr/news-in-english/arthro-news-in-english/36238/marinakis-accused-for-bribery/ | title=Marinakis accused for bribery | publisher = sdna.gr | date = 13 May 2015}}</ref> exploiting the self-governing ("autonomy") status of national football federations promoted by [[FIFA]] and [[UEFA]]. Referees, judges, football directors and chairmen are also involved in the scandal. All defendants deny charges. [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]] are the champions of the [[Superleague Greece|Greek Superleague]] at the time.
==Prosecutor's conclusion==
===Organization's beginnings=== {{see also|Koriopolis}}
In the summer of 2011, the Greek football was under the storm of [[Koriopolis]] scandal, a massive [[Match fixing|match-fixing]] case with many officials involved, including [[Evangelos Marinakis]], the new owner of [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]].
According to the recent prosecutor's conclusion, [[Evangelos Marinakis]], Theodoros Kouridis, Aristidis Stathopoulos, Georgios Sarris and [[Ένωση Ποδοσφαιρικών Σωματείων Ευβοίας|Euboea Football Clubs Association]] president Ioannis Papakonstantinou later met at [[Hilton Athens|Hilton Hotel]] in Athens in December 2011. The decisions that they came up with after their meeting were to support Sarris' candidation for the presidency of the [[Hellenic Football Federation|Greek Football Federation]] in the upcoming election, aiming to control it, and that [[Evangelos Marinakis]] would have a leading role in the organization.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://directnews.gr/athletics/60110-olo-to-porisma-tou-eisaggelea-ar-korea-gia-ta-sthmena-sto-podosfairo-protagonistikos-o-rolos-tou-vaggelh-marinakh-eggrafa.html | script-title = el:Πόρισμα εισαγγελέα Αριστείδη Κορρέα για την ύπαρξη εγκληματικής οργάνωσης στο ποδόσφαιρο | page = 160 | language = Greek | publisher = Public Prosecutor's Office of District Court Judges | date = 3 December 2014 | accessdate = 6 April 2015 | title = Archived copy | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150410102133/http://directnews.gr/athletics/60110-olo-to-porisma-tou-eisaggelea-ar-korea-gia-ta-sthmena-sto-podosfairo-protagonistikos-o-rolos-tou-vaggelh-marinakh-eggrafa.html | archive-date = 10 April 2015 | dead-url = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
One of the first actions of the new presidency of HFF was the replacement of the two football prosecutors (Fakos, Antonakakis) with two others (Petropoulos, Karras).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdna.gr/gr/podosfairo/dikastikes-upotheseis-skandala/arthro/25841/eisaggeleas-gia-tous-eisaggeleis-uparhei/|title=Εισαγγελέας για τους εισαγγελείς υπάρχει;|publisher=|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> The investigation inside the Federation for the [[Koriopolis]] scandal stopped and never resumed ever since.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contra.gr/Soccer/Hellas/oristhkan-oi-neoi-athlhtikoi-eisaggeleis.1602153.html|title=Ορίστηκαν οι νέοι αθλητικοί εισαγγελείς|date=2 February 2012|work=Contra.gr|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Konstantineas bakery bombing.jpg|thumb|left|Konstantineas' bakery after the bomb explosion]] -->
In January 2012, Kouridis and Stathopoulos following [[Evangelos Marinakis|Marinakis]] orders, secretly met referee [[Petros Konstantineas]], currently a member of the [[Hellenic Parliament]] and a key participant in the fight against football corruption,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.hellenicparliament.gr/en/Vouleftes/Ana-Koinovouleftiki-Omada/?MPId=892c0af0-c4e0-406e-8d1a-a43400eba3cd | script-title=el:Member of Parliament }}</ref> and demanded from him to favour [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]] against [[Skoda Xanthi F.C.|Xanthi]] at their 22 January 2012 clash.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://tvxs.gr/news/ellada/sto-fos-porisma-gia-ta-stimena-sto-elliniko-podosfairo | script-title=el:Πόρισμα εισαγγελέα Αριστείδη Κορρέα για την ύπαρξη εγκληματικής οργάνωσης στο ποδόσφαιρο | page=161 | language = Greek | publisher = Public Prosecutor's Office of District Court Judges | date = 3 December 2014 | accessdate = 6 April 2015}}</ref> Konstantineas refused and [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]] were defeated by [[Skoda Xanthi F.C.|Xanthi]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.apn.gr/news/sports/xanthi-olympiakos-1-0-videos/ | script-title=el:Scoda Xanthi – Olympiakos 1–0 | date = 22 January 2012}}</ref> A month later, according to the prosecutor, [[Evangelos Marinakis|Marinakis]] allegedly ordered unknown people to [[Explosive material#Low explosives|bomb]] Konstantineas' bakery, which led to bakery's demolition on 23 February 2012,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pelopsnews.gr/news.php?id=1160 | script-title=el:Τίναξαν στον αέρα το φούρνο του διαιτητή Π. Κωνσταντινέα στην Καλαμάτα | date = 23 February 2012 | language = greek }}</ref> an incident that "established [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]]' president domination on [[Football in Greece|Greek football]]".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://tvxs.gr/news/ellada/sto-fos-porisma-gia-ta-stimena-sto-elliniko-podosfairo | script-title=el:Πόρισμα εισαγγελέα Αριστείδη Κορρέα για την ύπαρξη εγκληματικής οργάνωσης στο ποδόσφαιρο | page=162 | language = Greek | publisher = Public Prosecutor's Office of District Court Judges | date = 3 December 2014 | accessdate = 6 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/sport/fussball/olympiakos-muss-gewinnen-korruption-in-griechenland-13106395.html|title=Olympiakos muss gewinnen: Korruption in Griechenland|author=Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung GmbH|date=20 August 2014|work=FAZ.NET|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref>
===Expanding activity===
[[Evangelos Marinakis|Marinakis]], Kouridis and Sarris used [[prepaid mobile phone]]s owned typically by Chinese and [[Pakistanis|Pakistani]] immigrants so as to communicate avoiding surveillance from the [[National Intelligence Service (Greece)|National Intelligence Service of Greece]], although they were eventually wiretapped nonetheless. The phone [[Evangelos Marinakis|Marinakis]] used was registered to a Pakistani individual named "Fataul Haque", while Sarris' phone was registered to a Chinese one named "Qianqian Zhang".<ref>{{cite web | url = http://tvxs.gr/news/ellada/sto-fos-porisma-gia-ta-stimena-sto-elliniko-podosfairo | script-title=el:Πόρισμα εισαγγελέα Αριστείδη Κορρέα για την ύπαρξη εγκληματικής οργάνωσης στο ποδόσφαιρο | page=94 | language = Greek | publisher = Public Prosecutor's Office of District Court Judges | date = 3 December 2014 | accessdate = 6 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideworldfootball.com/world-football/europe/16904-greek-corruption-olympiacos-owner-charged-in-match-fixing-ring-round-up|title=Greek corruption: Olympiacos owner charged in match-fixing ring round-up - Inside World Football|author=Paul Nicholson|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideworldfootball.com/matt-scott/16944-matt-scott-greek-football-s-tragedy-is-a-lesson-for-us-all |title=Matt Scott: Greek football's tragedy is a lesson for us all - Inside World Football |author=Paul Nicholson |publisher= |accessdate=16 August 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924035231/http://www.insideworldfootball.com/matt-scott/16944-matt-scott-greek-football-s-tragedy-is-a-lesson-for-us-all |archivedate=24 September 2015 }}</ref>
Korreas' conclusion states that [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]] owner's influence expanded to a wider range beyond his own club and that following his interests, various illegallities were committed. Specific referees were ordered so as to favor [[Platanias F.C.]], a club that was under [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]]' influence, against [[Panachaiki F.C.]] in a 2012 [[Football League (Greece)|Football League]] play-off match which led to [[Platanias F.C.]] promoting to [[Superleague Greece|Super League]]. He intervened in [[Football League (Greece)|Football League]]'s Disciplinary Committee work in order to evoke favorable decisions for [[Tyrnavos 2005 F.C.]] against [[Niki Volos F.C.|Niki Volou]].<ref name="scribd.com">{{cite web | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/264541497/3-%CE%A0%CF%8C%CF%81%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%BC%CE%B1-%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%B1%CE%B3%CE%B3%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%AD%CE%B1-%CE%9A%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%81%CE%AD%CE%B1-%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD-%CE%B5%CE%B3%CE%BA%CE%BB%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%B9%CE%BA%CE%AE-%CE%BF%CF%81%CE%B3%CE%AC%CE%BD%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7-%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF-%CF%80%CE%BF%CE%B4%CF%8C%CF%83%CF%86%CE%B1%CE%B9%CF%81%CE%BF | script-title=el:Πόρισμα εισαγγελέα Αριστείδη Κορρέα για την ύπαρξη εγκληματικής οργάνωσης στο ποδόσφαιρο | page=163 | language = Greek | publisher = Public Prosecutor's Office of District Court Judges | date = 3 December 2014 | accessdate = 6 April 2015}}</ref> Most important, he managed to influence most of the [[Local football championships of Greece|local Football Clubs Associations]] across Greece as well as most of the [[Superleague Greece|Super League]] clubs, which out of subordination and financial survival reasons agreed and aided [[Evangelos Marinakis|Marinakis]]' right-hand Giorgos Sarris to become elected as the new president of [[Hellenic Football Federation|Greek Football Federation]].<ref name="scribd.com"/>
The prosecutor's conclusion goes on mentioning that [[Superleague Greece|Super League]]'s control was taken using [[Evangelos Marinakis|Marinakis]]' stated power and economic strength.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://descrier.co.uk/sport/fifas-mafia-family-just-got-bigger/ | title=Fifa’s "Mafia family" just got bigger | publisher = Descrier | date = 15 October 2014}}</ref> [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]] even maintains a large roster aiming to loan players to weaker clubs, succeeding in that manner to "preserve their influence along the league". Club's officials have been recorded by the [[National Intelligence Service (Greece)|National Intelligence Service of Greece]] of even demanding and eventually managing to place in [[Panionios F.C.|Panionios]]' manager position [[Dimitrios Eleftheropoulos]], Olympiacos' former goalkeeper, paying half of his contract salary.<ref name="scribd.com"/>
===Expanding violence=== Various acts of violence are also included inside the prosecutor's conclusion against referees (Giorgos Daloukas, Dimitris Kyrkos etc.), journalists and others. In a separate case, launched in July 2011, Marinakis is accused also of instigation and facilitating acts of [[Violence in sports|violence]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_wsite5_1_11/07/2011_397915|title = Vangelis Marinakis in fresh trouble|date = July 11, 2011|accessdate = |website = Ekathimerini|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> According to telephone recordings, Marinakis, along with the president of [[Second Division (Greece)|second-division]] club [[Ilioupoli F.C.|Ilioupoli]], Giorgos Tsakogiannis, and others, cooperated so that a group of hardcore Olympiakos fans would travel on March 13, 2011 to a [[Third Division (Greece)|third division]] match and provoke [[riots]] to bring about a penalty. The prosecutor’s report says that "Tsakogiannis informed [Ioannis] [[Papadopoulos]] that he had made arrangements and Evangelos Marinakis was aware of the plan for Olympiakos fans to cause riots".<ref name=":1" />
In one of the recorded conversations, the ex-board member of Olympiakos [[Emilios Kotsonis]] (currently imprisoned for a case of a ship with two tonnes [[heroin]], which was caught by the Greek authorities with the help of the [[US Drug Enforcement Administration]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/greece/10919089/Greek-Coast-Guard-seize-over-two-tons-of-heroin.html|title=Greek Coast Guard seize over two tons of heroin|author=AP|date=23 June 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref>) refers to the severe crowd violence during a derby match of Panathinaikos against Olympiakos ([[2011–12 Superleague Greece|2011–12 season]]), for which Panathinaikos was docked three points and punished €212.000 as fine, saying that [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] was behind the incident.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdna.gr/gr/podosfairo/superleague/panathinaikos/arthro/44681/hrusaugites-piso-apo-ta-epeisodia-sto-derbi-aionion/|title=SPORTSDNA - ΠΟΔΟΣΦΑΙΡΟ - Superleague - Παναθηναϊκός - Χρυσαυγίτες πίσω από τα επεισόδια στο ντέρμπι "αιωνίων"|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref>
===Consequent state=== Sarris, Kouridis and Stathopoulos along with their colleagues and former referees Briakos and Douros, compiled the referees' charts for the 2011–12 and 2012–13 seasons of Greek Leagues, including referees of their utmost trust, such as Ioannidis, Amparkiolis and Kampaksis, who were used in crucial games in favor of the organization's interests. Among others, they refereed the match of [[Apollon Smyrni F.C.]] against [[Panionios F.C.|Panionios]], being ordered to favour [[Panionios F.C.|Panionios]], as well as the match of [[Levadiakos F.C.]] against [[Panetolikos F.C.]], being ordered to favour Levadiakos.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web | url = https://www.scribd.com/doc/264541497/3-%CE%A0%CF%8C%CF%81%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%BC%CE%B1-%CE%B5%CE%B9%CF%83%CE%B1%CE%B3%CE%B3%CE%B5%CE%BB%CE%AD%CE%B1-%CE%9A%CE%BF%CF%81%CF%81%CE%AD%CE%B1-%CE%B3%CE%B9%CE%B1-%CF%84%CE%B7%CE%BD-%CE%B5%CE%B3%CE%BA%CE%BB%CE%B7%CE%BC%CE%B1%CF%84%CE%B9%CE%BA%CE%AE-%CE%BF%CF%81%CE%B3%CE%AC%CE%BD%CF%89%CF%83%CE%B7-%CF%83%CF%84%CE%BF-%CF%80%CE%BF%CE%B4%CF%8C%CF%83%CF%86%CE%B1%CE%B9%CF%81%CE%BF | script-title=el:Πόρισμα εισαγγελέα Αριστείδη Κορρέα για την ύπαρξη εγκληματικής οργάνωσης στο ποδόσφαιρο | page=164 | language = Greek | publisher = Public Prosecutor's Office of District Court Judges | date = 3 December 2014 | accessdate = 6 April 2015}}</ref> Levadiakos' owner Giannis Kompotis, having acquaintances among the organization's circle, regularly benefit from them.
Concluding, the prosecutor points up that [[Evangelos Marinakis|Marinakis]] managed to currently dominate Greek football using his power and subsequent alliances and that furthermore, taking advantage of the situation, [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]] have been winning the Greek [[Superleague Greece|Super League]] each season since [[2010–11 Superleague Greece|2011]], an achievement that automatically gives the club the income reward of around €20 million per year out of [[UEFA Champions League#Prize money|UEFA's market pool]]<ref name="ReferenceA"/> resulting from their subsequent participation in the [[UEFA Champions League]] Group Phase.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sdna.gr/gr/news-in-english/arthro-news-in-english/36504/panathinaikos-and-paok-set-to-sue-olympiakos-to-uefa/ | title=Panathinaikos and PAOK set to sue Olympiakos to UEFA | publisher = sdna.gr | date = 13 May 2015}}</ref> In one of the recorded conversations, the [[UEFA]]'s Deputy General Secretary, [[Theodore Theodoridis]], partner of [[Michel Platini]] and son of vice-president of Olympiakos Savvas Theodoridis, is heard to provide help to Marinakis. Theodoridis is appearing to be the person who is responsible for the good relations between Platini and the various Football Federations ensuring his reelection.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.cahiersdufootball.net/article-olympiakos-grosses-combines-relations-troubles-6011 | title=Olympiakos: Grosses Combines et relations troubles | publisher = les cahiers du football | date = 9 September 2015}}</ref>
According to the Greek sports-site ''sdna.gr'' the Greek Federation has copied the code of [[FIFA Ethics Committee]], but removing all the rules referring to punishments of officials, aiming to self-protection. The Federation still refuses to send its articles of association to the [[Greek General Secretary of Sports]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sdna.gr/podosfairo/peitharxikes-apofaseis/article/123691/epo-colpo-grosso-atimorisias | title=ΕΠΟ: Colpo grosso ατιμωρησίας | publisher = sdna.grl | date = 11 October 2015}}</ref>
== Other testimonies and statements == In 2014, [[Stamatis Vellis]], ex-president of [[Apollon Smyrni]], testified to the district attorney that the fate of his team depended on actions of corrupted members of the [[Hellenic Football Federation]], naming a number of officials currently accused, and for that reason he quit from the presidency of his club and the Greek football.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iapopsi.gr/kataggelies-velli/|title=Καταγγελίες Βελλή!|author=X. M.|work=Η Άποψη|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref>
In September 2014, [[Olivier Kapo]], a former player of [[Levadiakos F.C.]], confirmed the alleged existence of a criminal organization within the Greek football industry, when he stated in the French press that in Greek football, “everything is corrupted [and] mafia-controlled.”<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sofoot.com/olivier-kapo-en-grece-c-est-la-mafia-totale-188629.html|title = Olivier Kapo:" En Grèce, c'est la mafia totale !"|date = September 3, 2014|accessdate = October 31, 2014|website = |publisher = |last = |first = |language = French}}</ref>
Ex-player of Panathinaikos, [[Gordon Schildenfeld]]’s sensational allegations about corruption in Greek football have caused uproar as he claimed: “I wanted to kill some of the refs in Greece. If I killed as many referees as I wanted you wouldn’t have had too many more in the Greek Superleague to officiate.”<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/6663672/Platini-must-fix-Greek-farce.html|title=Platini must fix Greek farce|publisher=|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref>
On 27 May 2015, the President of the [[Thessaly Football Clubs Association|Football Union of Thessaly]], Anastasios Batziakas (head of a Union which appealed the current presidency of the [[Hellenic Football Federation]] due to corruption), testified that his life was threatened by anonymous calls.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sdna.gr/gr/podosfairo/ellada/article/40079/apeiles-kataggelei-o-proedros-pou-thelei-na-rixei-tin-epo/ | script-title=el:Απειλές καταγγέλει ο πρόεδρος που θέλει να ρίξει την ΕΠΟ» | language = Greek | publisher = sdna.gr | date = 27 May 2015}}</ref>
In August 2015, Petros Konstantineas stated that the referees in Greece should be professionals and criticized the situation about [[Hugh Dallas]] for getting paid without having any jurisdiction. He described also the [[Hellenic Football Federation|Football Federation]] as a company who "pop in and out the Greek courts" and that [[Syriza]] "is going to finish the job".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerplus.gr/article/56962-kostantineas-parea-poy-mpainobgainei-stin-eyelpidon-epo|title=Κωσταντινέας: "Παρέα που μπαινοβγαίνει στην Ευελπίδων η ΕΠΟ|author=soccerplus.gr|date=25 August 2015|publisher=|accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref>
On 2 March 2016, the owner oF [[PAOK FC]], [[Ivan Savvidis]], criticized the [[Hellenic Football Federation]]'s officials and referees, stating at TV that "he is ashamed to be linked with the Greek football" and asked the resignation of Olympiakos' president, Marinakis, and the Federation's president.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdna.gr/podosfairo/kypello-elladas/article/174800/xeimaros-o-savvidis-den-tha-katevoyme-stin-athina|title="Χείμαρρος" ο Σαββίδης: "Δεν θα κατέβουμε στην Αθήνα, να παραιτηθεί ο Μαρινάκης"! |author=sdna.gr|date=3 March 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 March 2016}}</ref> The board of directors of PAOK also asked the resignation of the Federation's president and the expulsion of all the accused persons from the Greek football, such as arbitration with foreign referees from the next season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contra.gr/Soccer/Hellas/GreekCup/paok/pae-paok-h-omada-den-tha-agwnistei-ston-epanalhptiko-kypelloy.3938069.html|title=Η ομάδα δεν θα αγωνιστεί στον επαναληπτικό Κυπέλλου |author=contra.gr|date=3 March 2016|publisher=|accessdate=3 March 2016}}</ref>
On 18 March 2016, [[Panathinaikos FC]] President [[Giannis Alafouzos]] sued Mr Marinakis and judges Tziblakis and Poulios for the [[Koriopolis]] case.<ref>[http://sports.in.gr/football/superleague/article/?aid=1500065801 Μήνυση στον Άρειο Πάγο από Αλαφούζο για το «Koriopolis»]</ref>
== Current judicial status ==
As of June 2015, suspects are being questioned by investigating judge Georgios Andreadis. Andreadis added 10 suspects to the 16 that prosecutor Aristidis Korreas had proposed.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.efsyn.gr/arthro/aytoi-einai-oi-26-katigoroymenoi-tis-egklimatikis-organosis | script-title=el:Αυτοί είναι οι 26 κατηγορούμενοι της «εγκληματικής οργάνωσης» | language = Greek | publisher = Efimerida Syntakton | date = 29 April 2015}}</ref> Court council is due to decide who are to put on trial.
[[Evangelos Marinakis]] was questioned on 18 June 2015 and he was released on a €200,000 bail. He is also forced to stop being involved in any football activity, as well as he must report to a police station every 15 days.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9888897/olymiakos-owner-vangelis-marinakis-banned-from-football-over-corruption-allegations | title=Olympiakos owner Vangelis Marinakis banned from football over corruption allegations | publisher = skysports.com | date = 18 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.eurosport.com/football/owner-of-greek-champions-banned-over-corruption-probe_sto4787854/story.shtml | title=Owner of Greek champions banned over corruption probe | publisher = eurosport.com | date = 18 June 2015}}</ref>
===Koriopolis progress=== In July 2015, and after the prosecutor's proposal to the penal justice, it was announced that are going to be tried for the [[Koriopolis]]: the players [[Avraam Papadopoulos]], [[Kostas Mendrinos]], the officials Achilleas Beos, Ioannis Kombotis (owner of [[Levadiakos F.C.]]), Dimitris Tzelepis (chairman of [[Panthrakikos F.C.]]), Giorgos Borovilos (president of [[Asteras Tripolis]]), Dimitris Bakos (owner of Asteras Tripolis), Michalis Kountouris (president of amateur [[Olympiacos CFP]] and board member of [[Olympiacos F.C.]]) and many more.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideworldfootball.com/world-football/europe/17545-greeks-send-85-to-trial-for-match-fixing-but-olympiakos-boss-clears-first-round|title=Greeks send 85 to trial for match-fixing, but Olympiakos boss clears first round - Inside World Football|author=Paul Nicholson|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gazzetta.gr/football/article/780885/apallagi-marinaki-se-diki-85-atoma|title=Απαλλαγή Μαρινάκη, σε δίκη 85 άτομα|author=Gazzetta team|date=30 July 2015|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref> On 5 Steptember 2015, a new conversation recorded by the [[National Intelligence Service (Greece)|National Intelligence Service]] came in the light, with the ex-board member of Olympiakos [[Emilios Kotsonis]] asking for a meeting from a judge of the case (Giannis Tziblakis) with [[Evangelos Marinakis]], who was finally cleared for Koriopolis. In the case intervened the [[Court of Cassation (Greece)|Court of Cassation]], the supreme court of Greece for civil and criminal law, and the case for Marinakis is going to be examined again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdna.gr/podosfairo/dikastikes-apofaseis/article/122000/paremvasi-areioy-pagoy-gia-skandalo-koriopolis|title=Παρέμβαση Αρείου Πάγου για το σκάνδαλο "Koriopolis"!|publisher=|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref>
=== Additional suspects ===
Additional suspects include [[Veria F.C.]] Director of Football Giorgos Lanaris and former owner Giorgos Arvanitidis, regarding 6 January 2013 match of [[Olympiakos F.C.]] against Veria.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sdna.gr/gr/news-in-english/arthro-news-in-english/38394/six-veroia-players-accused-of-bribery/ | title=Six Veroia players accused of bribery | publisher = sdna.gr | date = 20 May 2015}}</ref> Veria player [[Nikolaos Georgeas]] and club's manager [[Dimitris Kalaitzidis]] at the time, testified in March 2015 that Lanaris following Arvanitidis orders demanded from Veria players to lose with a 3–0 score, which eventually happened.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ethnos.gr/ethnosport/article.asp?catid=8356&subid=2&pubid=130058828 | script-title=el:Το δικαστικό... ντέρμπι της Βέροιας κρίνει τη μάχη της παραμονής | language = Greek | publisher = Ethnos Newspaper | date = 10 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G2BmIRMIgiI | script-title=el:4η Αγ. ΟΛΥΜΠΙΑΚΟΣ – ΒΕΡΟΙΑ 3–0 | date = 20 September 2014}}</ref> According to Andreadis, both [[Evangelos Marinakis|Marinakis]] and Arvanitidis had agreed on the match fixing.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sport24.gr/football/omades/Olympiakos/kathgoroumenos-gia-to-olympiakos-veroia-o-marinakhs.3463504.html | script-title=el:Κατηγορούμενος ο Μαρινάκης για το Ολυμπιακός-Βέροια | language = Greek | date = 12 May 2014}}</ref> Guillermo Pérez, football player of Veria at that time, stated also to the prosecutor that the game was fixed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdna.gr/podosfairo/dikastikes-apofaseis/article/120097/omologia-vomva-gia-olympiakos-veroia-3-0|title=Ομολογία - βόμβα για το Ολυμπιακός-Βέροια 3-0|publisher=|accessdate=23 December 2015}}</ref> However, Veria was judged as innocent for the suspected fixed match against Olympiakos by the appeal committee of the Football Federation.
[[Atromitos F.C.]] football director Giannis Agkelopoulos along with club's owner Giorgos Spanos were also questioned by Andreadis on the suspicion of manipulating 4 February 2015 match of [[Olympiakos F.C.|Olympiakos]] against [[Atromitos F.C.|Atromitos]], following [[Panathinaikos F.C.]] football director [[Takis Fyssas]] testimony. Fyssas claimed that Atromitos coach at that time, [[Ricardo Sá Pinto]], had shared with him that Agkelopoulos demanded from the coach not to use [[Miguel Sebastián Garcia|Pitu Garcia]], [[Stefano Napoleoni|Napoleoni]], [[Kostas Katsouranis|Katsouranis]] and Kivrakidis for the match in question.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.efsyn.gr/arthro/peraste-kosme | script-title=el:Περάστε κόσμε... | language = Greek | publisher = Efimerida Syntakton | date = 21 April 2015}}</ref> At the questioning, Agkelopoulos and Spanos handed over a letter written by [[Ricardo Sa Pinto|Sa Pinto]] claiming that the story is not true,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.newsit.gr/default.php?pname=Article&art_id=391486&catid=1 | script-title=el:Δήλωσε άγνοια για τις... παρεμβάσεις ο Σα Πίντο | language = Greek | date = 20 April 2015}}</ref> while [[Takis Fyssas|Fyssas]] claims the story is known even by [[Fernando Santos (football coach)|Fernando Santos]]' assistant, Ricardo Santos. Santos confirmed him after talking to the Press, stating that he had informed Fyssas through a text message which then became part of the latter's testimony.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.zougla.gr/sports/article/fisas-skopos-mou-itan-mono-na-metafero-tin-ali8ia | script-title=el:Φύσσας: «Σκοπός μου ήταν μόνο να μεταφέρω την αλήθεια» | language = Greek | date = 6 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sdna.gr/gr/podosfairo/arthro/35156/rikardo-o-fussas-de-leei-psemata/ | script-title=el:Ρικάρντο: «Ο Φύσσας δεν λέει ψέματα!» | language = Greek | date = 7 May 2015}}</ref>
=== UEFA's reaction === On June 30, 2015, UEFA's General secretary [[Gianni Infantino]] stated that Olympiakos will keep their spot in the Champions League for the time,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.themalaymailonline.com/sports/article/olympiakos-champions-league-spot-safe-for-now-despite-owners-crime-scandal | title=Olympiakos' Champions League spot safe for now despite owner's crime scandal | date = 30 June 2015}}</ref> such as Asteras Tripoli FC. Later, the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] confirmed the participation of Olympiakos in the Champions League.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.insideworldfootball.com/world-football/europe/17727-match-fixing-who-cares-cas-backs-uefa-over-olympiacos-despite-athens-court-bans | title= Match-fixing? Who cares? | date = 26 August 2015}}</ref>
On 17 June 2015, the English sports-site [http://www.insideworldfootball.com Inside World Football] had revealed that UEFA's integrity officer for the [[Hellenic Football Federation|HFF]] (Dimitris Davakis) didn't state to the UEFA's Ethics and Disciplinary Inspector, [[Miguel Liétard Fernandez-Palacios]], the judicial process and the alleged involvement of [[Asteras Tripoli]] in the Greek match-fixing scandal of [[Koriopolis]], regarding their participation in the [[UEFA Europa League]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.insideworldfootball.com/world-football/europe/17247-exclusive-uefa-ethics-chiefs-clears-greeks-in-match-fixing-scandal-for-europa-league|title=Exclusive: UEFA ethics chief clears Greeks in match-fixing scandal for Europa League - Inside World Football|author=Paul Nicholson|publisher=|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref>
According to the ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]]'', UEFA did not respond to a request to confirm whether Infantino’s deputy, Theodore Theodoridis, had recused himself from any discussions or decisions about the handling of the Olympiakos case, because of the relationship of Theodoridis’s father, Savvas, vice-president of Olympiakos, and Theodoridis Jnr.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/news/11742597/Match-fixing-case-in-Greece-just-adds-to-sense-of-Greek-chaos.html|title=Match-fixing case in Greece just adds to sense of Greek chaos|date=15 July 2015|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=16 August 2015}}</ref>

page.title: Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967

revision.text:
The '''Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967''' ('''ADEA'''; {{usc|29|621}} to {{usc|29|634}}) is a [[US labor law]] that forbids [[employment]] [[discrimination]] against anyone at least 40 years of age in the [[United States]] (see {{usc|29|631}}). In 1967, the bill was signed into law by President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]]. The ADEA prevents [[ageism|age discrimination]] and provides equal employment opportunity under conditions that were not explicitly covered in [[Title VII]] of the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Glenn|first1=Jeremy J.|last2=Little|first2=Katelan E.|title=A Study of the Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967|journal=GPSolo|date=November 2014|volume=31|issue=6}}</ref> It also applies to the standards for [[pensions]] and [[employment benefits|benefits provided by employers]], and requires that information concerning the needs of older workers be provided to the general public.
==Scope of protection== The ADEA includes a broad ban against age discrimination against workers over the age of forty,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=Age Discrimination Law|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/employment/age_discrimination.html|website=ExpertLaw|accessdate=28 September 2017|date=25 July 2016}}</ref> and also specifically prohibits:
* Discrimination in [[Recruitment|hiring]], promotions, wages, and [[termination of employment]] and [[layoffs]]. * Statements of specifications in age preference or limitations. * Denial of benefits to older employees: an employer may reduce benefits based on age only if the cost of providing the reduced benefits to older workers is the same as the cost of providing full benefits to younger workers. * Since 1986, it has prohibited mandatory retirement in most sectors, with phased elimination of mandatory retirement for tenured workers, such as college professors, in 1993.
Mandatory retirement based on age is permitted for: * Executives over age 65 in high policy-making positions who are entitled to a pension over a minimum yearly amount.
The ADEA applies to employers who employ at least twenty employees on a regular basis within the current or prior calendar year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Thresholds for Coverage Under Employment-Related Laws|url=http://www.twc.state.tx.us/news/efte/thresholds_for_coverage.html|website=Texas Workforce Commission|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref>
==Amendments== The ADEA was first amended in 1986, and then again in 1991 by the Older Workers Benefit Protection Act (Pub. L. 101-433) and the [[Civil Rights Act of 1991]] (Pub. L. 102-166).
==Case law== The ADEA differs from the Civil Rights Act in that the ADEA applies to employers of 20 or more employees (see {{usc|29|630(b)}}) rather than 15 or more employees. Both acts do, however, only apply to employers in industries affecting interstate commerce. The 20 employees can include overseas employees.<ref>{{cite web|title=Morelli v. Cedel 141 F.3d 39, 45 (2nd Cir. 1998)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=3529498746539865340|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref>
The ADEA protects US citizens working for US employers operating abroad except where it would violate the laws of that country.<ref name="29usc623">See subsection (f)(1), {{cite web|title=29 U.S. Code Sec. 623 - Prohibition of age discrimination|url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/29/623|website=Legal Information Institute|publisher=Cornell Law School|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Mahoney v. RFE/RL, Inc., 47 F.3d 447, 449 (DC Cir. 1995)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=17350426720272097522|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref>
An age limit may be legally specified in the circumstance where age has been shown to be a "[[bona fide occupational qualification]] [BFOQ] reasonably necessary to the normal operation of the particular business" (see {{usc|29|623(f)(1)}}). In practice, BFOQs for age are limited to the obvious (hiring a young actor to play a young character in a movie) or when public safety is at stake (for example, in the case of age limits for pilots and bus drivers).
The ADEA does not stop an employer from favoring an older employee over a younger one, even when the younger one is over 40 years old.<ref>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/02-1080.ZS.html ''General Dynamics Land Sys., Inc. v. Cline'', 540 U.S. 581 (2004)]</ref>
The [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]], in [[List of United States Supreme Court cases, volume 554|''Meacham v. Knolls Atomic Power Lab'']], 554 U.S. 84 (2008), held that the employer, not the employee, bears the burden of proving that a layoff or other action that hurts older workers more than others was based not on age but on some other “reasonable factor.”<ref name=NYTimes01>{{cite news|last=Greenhouse|first=Linda|title=A Supreme Court Victory for Older Workers|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/20/washington/20scotus.html|accessdate=March 1, 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 20, 2008}}</ref>
In ''[[Gomez-Perez v. Potter]]'' (2008), the Supreme Court allowed federal workers who experience retaliation as a result of reporting age discrimination under the law to sue for damages.
In ''[[Kimel v. Florida Bd. of Regents]]'', 528 U.S. 62 (2000), the Supreme Court held that state employees cannot sue states for monetary damages under the ADEA in federal court. The [[EEOC]] may still enforce the ADEA against states, and state employees may still sue state officials for [[declaratory relief|declaratory]] and [[injunctive relief]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Feder |first=Jody |title=The Age Discrimination in Employment Act (ADEA): A Legal Overview |url=http://aging.senate.gov/crs/aging21.pdf |publisher=Congressional Research Service, June 23, 2010, p. 2 |accessdate=3 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110705135926/http://aging.senate.gov/crs/aging21.pdf |archivedate=5 July 2011 |df= }}</ref>
==Remedies== ADEA remedies include compensatory and punitive damages for employee or damages if reinstatement is not feasible and/or employer's violation is intentional.
==Defenses== Statutory<ref name="29usc623"/> defenses to ADEA claims include: * Employers may enforce waivers of age discrimination claims made without EEOC or court approval if the waiver is "knowing or voluntary."<ref>{{cite web|title=Blakeney v. Lomas Information Systems, Inc. 65 F3d 482, 484 (5th Cir. 1995)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=16607583013917153271|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> * Valid arbitration agreements between employers and employees covering the dispute are subject to compulsory arbitration and no court action can be brought.<ref>{{cite web|title=ilmer v. Interstate/Johnson Lane Corporation 500 US 20, 26, 111 S.Ct. 1647, 1652 (1991)|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar_case?case=9166001121208093862|website=Google Scholar|publisher=Google|accessdate=28 September 2017}}</ref> * Employers can [[Termination of employment|discharge]] or [[discipline]] an employee for "good cause," regardless of the employee's age. * Employers can take an action based on "reasonable factors other than age." * Bona fide occupational qualifications, seniority systems, employee benefit or early retirement plans. * Voluntary early retirement incentives.
==See also== *[[US labor law]]

{{Refimprove|date=February 2011}} The '''[[Banu (arabic)|Banu]] Ka'b''' ({{lang-ar|بنو كعب}}) are an [[Arab]] nomadic tribe originating in the [[Najd]] region of [[Arabia]], who often raided, then settled various areas of southern and central [[Ottoman Iraq]], in cities such as [[Basra]] and [[Nasariyah]], and also across the border in the southernmost region of [[Khuzestan Province]] of [[Persia]], particularly near the city of [[Khorramshahr]]. From the early 18th century onwards, the Banu Ka'b began converting from [[Sunni]] to [[Shia Islam]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=agMu0nfdFZ4C&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Shi%27is+of+Iraq+By+Yitzhak+Nakash&as_brr=3 The Shi'is of Iraq By Yitzhak Nakash, pg. 27], and Haydari, ‘Unwan al-Majd, pg. 110-15, 118</ref>
Some members of this tribe are direct descendants of [[Muhammad]] through Imam [[Musa Al-Kadhim]], which makes them Sayyids. These Sayyids reside in Iraq.
Another branch of the Banu Ka'b settled in the areas that are now [[Oman]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]].
Individuals who are members of or are descended from the tribe often have the surname ''Kaabi'' or ''al-Kaabi''. Those from the tribe who reside within Iran often carry the dialectal spelling variant ''Chaab'' or ''Chabi''.
Banu Ka'b had their tribe flag as plain yellow banner. They have waged wars with neighbouring nations. For example, a famous naval battle, called Al-Raqah, occurred in the Persian Gulf between Bani Kaab and Kuwait. Bani Kaab were defeated by the Kuwaiti forces.

'''Böszörmény''', also '''Izmaelita''' ''(Hysmaelita / [[Ishmael]]ites)'' or '''Szerecsen''' ''(Saracens)'', is a name for the [[Muslim]]s who lived in the [[Kingdom of Hungary]] in the 10–13th centuries. Some of the ''Böszörmény'' probably joined the federation of the seven [[Magyar tribes]] during the 9th century, and later smaller groups of Muslims arrived in the [[Pannonian Basin|Carpathian Basin]]. They were engaged in trading but some of them were employed as mercenaries by the [[King of Hungary|kings of Hungary]]. Their rights were gradually restricted from the 11th century on, and they were coerced to accept baptism following the establishment of the [[Christian]] [[Kingdom of Hungary]]. They "disappeared" (probably became Christian) by the end of the 13th century.
==Origins== Modern authors claim that several groups of Muslims migrated to the Carpathian Basin in the course of the 10th–12th centuries; therefore, the Muslims living in the Kingdom of Hungary were composed of various ethnic groups. Most of them must have arrived from [[Volga Bulgaria]], but [[Toponymy|toponyms]] suggest that Muslim ('''káliz''': ''[[khalyzians]]'') people arrived also from [[Khwarezm]]; these latter (or part of them) may have formed one of the three tribes of the [[Kabar]]s who joined the federation of the Magyar tribes in the 9th century.
The Arab historian and geographer, [[Abu al-Hasan 'Alī al-Mas'ūdī|al-Mas'ūdī]] recorded in the 10th century that the heads of the tribal confederation had welcomed Muslim merchants and the merchants could even convert some of the Magyars into [[Islam]].<ref name='Peoples in Hungary'>{{cite book | last = Kristó | first = Gyula | title = Nem magyar népek a középkori Magyarországon ''(Non-Hungarian Peoples in the Medieval Hungary)'' | publisher = Lucidus Kiadó | date = 2003 | location = Budapest | isbn = 963-9465-15-1}}</ref> [[Abū 'Ubayd 'Abd Allāh al-Bakrī|Al-Bakrī]] also mentioned that the Magyars ransomed the Muslims who had been captured in the neighboring countries. In the 10th century, [[Abraham ben Jacob|Ibrahim ibn Yaqub]] described the Muslim merchants who arrived in [[Prague]] from the territories of the Magyars and traded with [[slavery|slaves]] and [[tin]]. The ''[[Gesta Hungarorum]]'' recorded that lots of Muslims arrived in the Carpathian Basin from Volga Bulgaria during the reign of [[Taksony of Hungary|Taksony]], Grand Prince of the Magyars ({{circa}} 955 – before 972) and they settled down there.<ref name='Peoples in Hungary' /> The work of the Muslim traveler, [[Abu Hamid al-Garnati]], who spent three years in the kingdom (1150–1153), proves that the Muslims living in the Kingdom of Hungary were composed of two groups: the [[Khwarezm]]ians and the ''Maghrebians'' (Böszörmény). He was entrusted by King [[Géza II of Hungary]] to recruit soldiers among the ''Maghrebians'' (Böszörmény) living east of the Carpathian Basin. The Byzantine historian [[John Kinnamos]] mentioned that ''káliz'' warriors were captured during the war between the kingdom and the Byzantine Empire in 1165 and the Emperor [[Manuel I Komnenos]] removed some of them to Byzantine territories.<ref name='Peoples in Hungary' />
==Muslim territories in the Kingdom of Hungary== The Muslims settled down in several groups in the Carpathian Basin. Their largest communities lived in the southern parts of the Kingdom of Hungary in [[Syrmia]] and in region where the [[Drava]] joins the [[Danube]]. Other significant groups of Muslims lived in and around [[Pest, Hungary|Pest]], in the [[Nyírség]] (around [[Hajdúböszörmény]]) and around [[Nitra]] ({{lang-hu|Nyitra}}).<ref name='Peoples in Hungary' /> The Arab geographer [[Yaqut al-Hamawi]] mentioned that Muslims from the Kingdom of Hungary were studying in [[Aleppo]] in the beginning of the 13th century. The students arrived in Aleppo from a frontier region of the kingdom where the Muslims lived in 30 settlements.<ref name='Peoples in Hungary' />
==The Muslims' life in the kingdom== Most of the Muslims in the Kingdom of Hungary were engaged in trading and they were rich enough to lease royal properties in the 13th century. Other Muslims were employed in the king's army and took part in the wars against the Byzantine Empire. Yaqut al-Hamawi's work proves that the Muslim population spoke the [[Hungarian language]] by the beginning of the 13th century.<ref name="Peoples in Hungary"/>
Royal decrees issued in the second half of the 11th century by the kings of Hungary persecuted the Muslims, requiring their conversion into Christianity. King [[Ladislaus I of Hungary]] commanded that converted Muslims who continued to follow Islam were to be removed from their original settlements. King [[Coloman of Hungary]] ordered that each Muslim settlement had to build a church, and he prohibited marriage between Muslims. Probably in the next century, the kings also prohibited the building of walls around Muslim settlements.
By the period of King Géza II (1141–1162), the ''káliz'' people could practise their faith only in secrecy. The "Maghrebian" soldiers followed Islam openly, but it was Abu Hamid al-Garnati who taught them several Islamic traditions. Upon his request, the king even permitted the "Maghrebians" to have concubines.<ref name="Peoples in Hungary"/>
==Muslims in the 13th century== The [[Golden Bull of 1222|Golden Bull]] of King [[Andrew II of Hungary|Andrew II]] prohibited the employment of Muslims as minters and tax collectors.<ref name='Történeti Kronológia'>{{cite book | last = Benda | first = Kálmán (editor) | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Magyarország történeti kronológiája ''("The Historical Chronology of Hungary")''| publisher = Akadémiai Kiadó | date = 1981 | location = Budapest | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 963-05-2661-1}}</ref> The king, however, continued to employ them in his administration. On 3 March 1231, [[Pope Gregory IX]] requested the prelates of the kingdom to protest against this practise and also authorized them to use ecclesiastical penalties for this reason. In the same year, King Andrew had to confirm the provisions of the Golden Bull but he still employed Muslims. Therefore, on 25 February 1232, Archbishop [[Robert of Esztergom]] placed the Kingdom of Hungary under an [[interdict]] and excommunicated some high dignitaries of the king. Pope Gregory IX sent a legate to the kingdom who reached an agreement with King Andrew on 20 August 1233 in [[Bereg County|Bereg]].<ref name='Történeti Kronológia' /> Under the agreement, the Muslims and the [[Jews]] could not hold royal offices and they were obliged to wear distinctive cloths. However, the king did not fulfill all the provisions of the agreement and therefore he was excommunicated, although he was absolved soon. On 10 December 1239, Pope Gregory IX even authorized King [[Béla IV of Hungary]] to lease his revenues to non-Christians.<ref name='Történeti Kronológia' />
Nevertheless, following the [[Mongol invasion of Europe|Mongol invasion of the kingdom]] (1241–1242) references to the Muslims in the kingdom became scarce. In 1290, King [[Ladislaus IV of Hungary]] appointed a former Muslim, [[Mizse]], to the office of the [[Palatine (Kingdom of Hungary)|Palatine]].
The ''Böszörmény'' denomination is preserved as a family name and in [[toponym]]s, such as [[Hajdúböszörmény]].<ref>[http://epa.niif.hu/00000/00021/00036/mksz2003_1_05.htm "History of Hungary"] {{hu icon}}</ref>

{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Chané (Izoceño) |image = [[File:El Fuerte Vista del lado.jpg|250px]] |caption = [[El Fuerte de Samaipata]], Chané ruins that predate the Inca, [[Samaipata, Bolivia]] |population = 1,500 |popplace = {{flag|Argentina}} 3,034 (2010) [http://www.estadistica.sanluis.gov.ar/estadisticaWeb/Contenido/Pagina148/File/LIBRO/censo2010_tomo1.pdf Censo Nacional de Población, Hogares y Viviendas 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160409013106/http://www.estadistica.sanluis.gov.ar/estadisticaWeb/Contenido/Pagina148/File/LIBRO/censo2010_tomo1.pdf |date=2016-04-09 }}
{{flag|Bolivia}}
{{flag|Paraguay}} |languages = [[Eastern Bolivian Guaraní language|Chiriguano]], [[Spanish language|Spanish]], formerly [[Chané language]] (an [[Arawakan language]])[https://archive.is/20130102110704/http://www.ethnologue.com/15/show_language.asp?code=caj "Chané."] ''Ethnologue.'' (retrieved 16 May 2011) |religions = [[Animism]], [[Christianity]]
([[Roman Catholicism]], [[Anglicanism]]) |related = }} '''Chané''' is the collective name for the southernmost [[Arawak language|Arawak-speaking]] peoples. They lived in the plains of the northern [[Gran Chaco]] and in the foothills of the [[Andes]] in [[Paraguay]], [[Brazil]], [[Bolivia]], and [[Argentina]]. The historical Chané are divided into two principal groups. The Chané proper who lived in eastern Bolivia and the Guaná who lived in Paraguay and adjacent Brazil. Twenty-first century survivors of the Chané are the Izoceno people of Bolivia and 3,034 descendants reported in Argentina by the 2010 census. Survivors of the Guaná are the [[Terena language|Tereno]] and the Kinikinao both of [[Mato Grosso do Sul]] province in Brazil.Censo Nacional de Poblacion, Hogares y Viviendas," https://www.indec.gov.ar/ftp/cuadros/poblacion/censo2010_tomo1.pdf, accessed 18 Dec 2017 Most of the historical Chané were subjects of and absorbed by the [[Eastern Bolivian Guarani]], commonly called Chiriguanos, while the Guaná were subjects of the [[Mbayá]], a [[Guaycuruan languages|Guaycuruan]] speaking people. ==History== The Chané, together with other [[Arawak peoples|Arawak]] groups, are believed to have originated in northeastern South America, but to have spread southward about 2,500 years ago. They developed an agrarian culture, built densely populated villages, cultivated corn, peanuts, cotton and squash, and are famous for their ceramics and graphics which have been found mainly in the pampas of Bolivia surrounding the city of [[Santa Cruz de la Sierra]] and in [[Samaipata, Bolivia|Samaipata]], [[Portachuelo]], Valle Abajo, Okinawa, [[Cotoca]], El Pari, Mataral and Warnes.Tras la Huella de los Chané, El Deber, June 1, 2003 They also craft wooden masks and fabric clothing. An ancient Chané religious site dating from about 300 CE is [[El Fuerte de Samaipata]], now a [[UNESCO World Heritage Site]].[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/883]. Accessed 23 Sep 2016 They were a rather peaceful culture and traded with the [[Quechua language|Quechua]]-speaking [[Inca]]s in the Andes and with other Arawak-speaking groups to the north and east. Chanés and Incas established a truce to join forces against the [[Eastern Guarani]] peoples of the Andes foothills, who the Incas and Spaniards called ''Chiriguanos''. The Chiriguanos raided the Chané homeland on a regular basis, and prior to the Spanish conquest, the Chiriguanos defeated the Chanés and halted the Inca advance into the plains and valleys of what is now the [[Santa Cruz Department (Bolivia)|Santa Cruz Department]] of [[Bolivia]]. Some Chane weré forced into slavery by the Chiriguanos, others migrated to less fertile regions to the southeast. Many Chané women were taken as wives by Chiriguano men, thus starting a process of assimilation. Both Guaraní and [[Guaraní language|Guaraní]]-speaking Chané also assimilated and mixed with Europeans during the colonial period and after the independence of both Argentina and Bolivia. ==The Guaná== The Guaná, (also called Layaná) are the eastern branch of the Chané. The were vassals of the Mbayá, a relationship that, according to Spanish accounts, existed in 1548, and possibly much earlier.Santos-Granero, Fernando (2009), ''Vital Enemies'', Austin: University of Texas Press, p. 38. Downloaded from [[Project Muse]]. The Guaná were agricultural and pedestrian as opposed to the nomadic Mbayá who became equestrians by the early 17th century. In the early 18th century the Guaná lived in seven large villages of 1,000 or more people on the western side of the Paraguay River between 19 and 22 south latitudes. Later in the 18th century, some of them migrated along with the Mbayá east of the Paraguay River. They were estimated, perhaps generously, in the early 18th century to have numbered 18,000 to 30,000. In 1793 they numbered about 8,200.Steward, pp. 239-240 The Guaná provided Mbayá chiefs with labor, agricultural products, textiles, and wives and in exchange were given protection and European goods such as iron tools by the Mbayá. The cultures of the Guaná and Mbayá slowly became more similar as the Mbayá adopted agriculture and weaving and the Guaná became equestrian. The Mbayá augmented their numbers, strictly limited by late marriages and [[abortion]], by intermarriage with Guaná and captive women of other ethnic groups.Saegar, pp. 18, 87-88, 116 Spanish chroniclers describe the Guaná as docile. The Mbayá, arrogant and ethnocentric, were described by Spanish chroniclers as surprisingly benign and respectful in dealing with their Guaná subjects.Hemming, John (1978), ''Red Gold: The Conquest of the Brazilian Indians,'' Cambridge: Harvard University Press, pp 394-395 In the late 18th century the Guaná, along with the Mbayá, migrated east of the Paraguay River, and by 1850 the Guaná had broken their relationship with the Mbayá and were living in the area of [[Miranda, Mato Grosso do Sul]], Brazil. The largest sub-tribe of the Guaná was the Tereno who numbered 3 to 4 thousand at the time.Steward, Julian H. (1946), ''Handbook of South American Indians, Volume 1, The Marginal Tribes'', Washington: Smithsonian Institution, pp 238-241 In 2001, they were called the Terêna, and 16,000 if them were living in the same area."Terêna", http://www.ethnologue.com/18/language/ter/, accessed 28 Dec 2017 ==Distribution== There are some Chané communities still living in the [[Izozog]] region in [[Santa Cruz, Bolivia]], and in [[Yacui]] and Che-Renda near [[Tartagal, Argentina]].[http://eprints.rclis.org/13555/1/Glosario_pueblos_indigenas.pdf Glosario de lenguas indígenas sudamericanas, Edgardo Civallero, Universidad Nacional de Córdoba]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In both cases, they have been influenced by the Guaraní language and culture, but still retain their Chane identity. The other descendants of the Chane culture were first mixed with the Guaranis, later with the Spaniards, and in the last two centuries with migration flows of other Europeans, Arabs, and migrants from other parts of Bolivia and Argentina. The Chane culture is an important heritage component of the populations of Santa Cruz, the Paraguayan Chaco, [[Salta Province]], [[Jujuy Province]] and the Argentine Chaco. ==See also== *[[Arawak peoples|Arawak]] *[[Chané language]] *[[Maipurean languages]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Immigration to Argentina}} {{Ethnic groups in Bolivia}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chane People}} [[Category:Indigenous peoples in Argentina]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples in Bolivia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Argentina]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Bolivia]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of the Gran Chaco]]

{{about|the Chief Federal Defender in Louisiana|the songwriter|Claude Kelly}} {{Infobox judge |honorific-prefix = |name = Claude John Kelly III |honorific-suffix = |image = |alt = |caption = |birth_name = Claude John Kelly III |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|04|30}} |birth_place = [[New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |restingplace = |restingplacecoordinates = |birthname = |citizenship = |nationality = |party = |otherparty = |spouse = |partner = |relations = |children = |residence = |alma_mater = [[College of the Holy Cross]] [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]]
[[Tulane University Law School]] [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] |occupation = |profession = Attorney |cabinet = |committees = |portfolio = |religion = |signature = |signature_alt = |website = |footnotes = }} '''Claude John Kelly III''' (born April 30, 1961) is the [[Federal public defender|Chief Federal Defender]] for the Eastern District of Louisiana and is a former nominee to be a [[United States federal judge|United States District Judge]] of the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana]]. ==Biography== Kelly received a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in 1983 from the [[College of the Holy Cross]]. He received a [[Juris Doctor]] in 1987 from [[Tulane University Law School]]. He began his legal career as an Assistant District Attorney with the [[New Orleans]] District Attorney's Office, from 1987 to 1990. He interrupted his legal career to serve as General Manager of his family's restaurant, Kolb's German Restaurant, from 1990 to 1992. He served as an Assistant Federal Public Defender in the Eastern District of Louisiana, from 1992 to 2000. He served as the Director of International Sales for Optimal Healthcare in [[Miami]], [[Florida]], from 2000 to 2002 and as a consultant for the International Exchange Group in [[Washington, D.C.]], from 2002 to 2006. From 2006 to 2014, he was in private practice as a solo practitioner, concentrating on criminal defense. Since 2014, he has served as the [[Federal public defender|Chief Federal Defender]] in the Federal Public Defender's Office for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/02/04/president-obama-nominates-two-serve-united-states-district-courts "President Obama Nominates Two to Serve on the United States District Courts" White House, February 4, 2016][http://www.katc.com/story/31144041/prosecutor-defense-lawyer-nominated-to-be-federal-judges "Prosecutor, defense lawyer nominated to be federal judges" KATC, February 4, 2016] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205123226/http://www.katc.com/story/31144041/prosecutor-defense-lawyer-nominated-to-be-federal-judges |date=February 5, 2016 }} ==Nomination to district court== On February 4, 2016, [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] nominated Kelly to serve as a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana, to the seat vacated by Judge [[Ivan L. R. Lemelle]], who took [[senior status]] on June 29, 2015.[https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2016/02/05/presidential-nominations-sent-senate "Presidential Nominations Sent to the Senate" White House, February 4, 2016] On May 18, 2016 the [[United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary|Judiciary Committee]] held a hearing on his nomination.[http://www.judiciary.senate.gov/meetings/05/18/2016/nominations United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary: Nominations for May 18, 2016] On June 16, 2016 his nomination was reported out of committee by [[voice vote]].[https://www.judiciary.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Results%20of%20Executive%20Business%20Meeting%2006-16-16.pdf Results of Executive Business Meeting – June 16, 2016, Senate Judiciary Committee] His nomination expired on January 3, 2017, with the end of the [[114th United States Congress|114th Congress]]. ==See also== * [[Barack Obama judicial appointment controversies]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kelly, Claude John III}} [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:College of the Holy Cross alumni]] [[Category:Louisiana lawyers]] [[Category:People from New Orleans]] [[Category:Public defenders]] [[Category:Tulane University Law School alumni]] {{US-law-bio-stub}}

[[File:Congressional Hispanic Conference.jpg|250px|thumb|right|CHC members in 2005 with Attorney General [[Alberto Gonzales]]]] {{Hispanic and Latino Americans}} The '''Congressional Hispanic Conference''' ('''CHC''') is a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]-controlled caucus in the [[United States Congress]]. Currently with six members,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://hispanicconference-mariodiazbalart.house.gov/membership |title= Members | author=<!--Not stated--> |website= Congressional Hispanic Conference |access-date= January 17, 2018}}</ref> the CHC was formed in 2003, with the stated goal of promoting policy outcomes of importance to Americans of [[Hispanic and Latino Americans|Hispanic or Latino]] and [[Portuguese American|Portuguese]] descent. These priorities included support of the following: then-President [[George W. Bush]] and American troops in the war against terrorism; the [[Free Trade Agreement of the Americas]] (FTAA); tax relief to families and the over two million Hispanic- and Portuguese-owned small businesses; support for [[faith based initiatives]]; and, educational choice for all. The impetus behind the Conference's creation was the debate surrounding the nomination of conservative lawyer [[Miguel Estrada]] to the [[DC Circuit Court of Appeals]].<ref name=people>Henry Bonilla, et al., [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB104786911197082300?mod=opinion%255Fmain%255Fcommentaries "We the (Hispanic) People...,"] ''Wall Street Journal'' (March 17, 2003)</ref><ref>Julian Pecquet, [http://www.adelantesi.com/Archive/Apr03/congresspeople_eng.htm "Latinos Take Over Washington,"] ''Adelante'' (April 2003)</ref> The Congressional Hispanic Conference should not be confused with the older [[Congressional Hispanic Caucus]], which is another congressional organization populated by [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] members of Congress.
==History== In the mid to late 1990s, the Republican members of the [[Congressional Hispanic Caucus]] – Mexican-American [[Henry Bonilla]] of Texas and Cuban-Americans [[Ileana Ros-Lehtinen]] and [[Lincoln Diaz-Balart]] of Florida – left the Caucus in protest over its support for improved relations with [[Cuba]].<ref name=form>Maria Recio, [http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/news/2003/3/19/hispanic_republicans_form_interest_group.htm "Hispanic Republicans Form Interest Group,"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130125073846/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/news/2003/3/19/hispanic_republicans_form_interest_group.htm |date=2013-01-25 }} ''HispanicBusiness.com'' (March 19, 2003)</ref> While Ros-Lehtinen remained an active member of the CHC's public outreach arm, the [[Congressional Hispanic Caucus Institute]], the Caucus has since been composed solely of Democratic and Democratic-caucusing independent legislators.<ref>CHCI, [http://www.chci.org/about/page/board-of-directors-2 Board of Directors] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090715172501/http://www.chci.org/about/page/board-of-directors-2 |date=2009-07-15 }} ''CHCI''. Accessed on May 5, 2009.</ref><ref>Congressional Hispanic Caucus, [http://velazquez.house.gov/chc/ CHC Main Page, Membership (sidebar)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090527232816/http://velazquez.house.gov/chc/ |date=2009-05-27 }} ''Office of Nydia Velasquez''. Accessed on May 31, 2009.</ref>
Feeling there was "significant need" for a "new Hispanic conference" newly elected Florida congressman [[Mario Diaz-Balart]] began to organize in 2002 a [[Congressional caucus|caucus]] for Hispanic Republicans to counter what they felt was Democratic dominance over Hispanic political affairs. On March 17, 2003, Diaz-Balart revealed the formation of the Conference in an open letter published in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.<ref name=people/> Joined by Bonilla, Ros-Lehtinen, his brother Lincoln, and newly elected colleague [[Devin Nunes]], a [[California]] congressman of Portuguese (Azorean) descent, Diaz-Balart decried what he perceived as Hispanic Democratic efforts to derail the nomination of Estrada, a selection seen by some at the time as a possible fast track to the [[Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court]].<ref name=form/><ref>Robert A. George, [http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/us_world/Sonia-Sotomayor-For-Life.html "Sonia Sotomayor (For life),"] ''NBC Washington.com'' (May 28, 2009)</ref> The group was officially announced at a press conference two days later. They were soon joined by two more [[Portuguese American]] congressmen, [[Richard Pombo]] of California and [[Patrick Toomey]] of Pennsylvania.<ref>Congressional Hispanic Conference, [http://www.hispanianews.com/archive/2003/11/14/03.htm "The Congressional Hispanic Conference Applauds the Passage of the Naturalization Bill for Immigrant Service Men and Women,"] (press release) ''Hispania News'' (November 14, 2003)</ref>
Like their Democratic counterpart, the Conference allows members from the [[United States Senate|Senate]]. [[Mel Martinez]], the first Cuban-American US Senator, joined the group shortly after his election in 2004. Additionally, the Conference is open to non-Hispanic "associate" members who represent districts with significant Hispanic populations or generally support its goals with regards to public policy.<ref>Office of Rep. J. Gresham Barrett, [http://www.house.gov/list/press/sc03_barrett/Hispanic_Conference.html "Congressman Gresham Barrett Joins the Congressional Hispanic Conference,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081101173428/http://www.house.gov/list/press/sc03_barrett/Hispanic_Conference.html |date=2008-11-01 }} (press release) ''House.gov'' (March 31, 2004)</ref><ref>Office of Rep. Bob Beauprez, [http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/news/2004/4/27/rep_bob_beauprez_of_colorado_joins.htm "Rep. Bob Beauprez of Colorado Joins the Congressional Hispanic Conference,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081014203612/http://www.hispanicbusiness.com/news/2004/4/27/rep_bob_beauprez_of_colorado_joins.htm |date=2008-10-14 }} (press release) ''HispanicBusiness.com'' (April 27, 2004)</ref> In 2003, Conference members also formed the [[Congressional Hispanic Leadership Institute]] as an equivalent to the Democratic CHC-affiliated CHCI.
In the 2006 and 2008 elections, the Conference suffered the loss of nearly half of their members to electoral defeat, attempts at higher office or resignations. Past chair [[Luis Fortuño]] left Congress after being elected [[Governor of Puerto Rico]]. After the [[United States elections, 2010|2010 midterm elections]], six new Hispanic Republicans were elected to Congress: Senator [[Marco Rubio]] of Florida, Representatives [[David Rivera]] of Florida, [[Raúl Labrador]] of [[Idaho]], [[Francisco Canseco]] and [[Bill Flores]] of Texas, and [[Jaime Herrera Beutler]] of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]], as well as Portuguese American Senator Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania, who was a member of the conference when he served in the House.

{{multiple image |direction = horizontal |align = right |width = 200 |footer = |image1 = |alt1 = |caption1 = Police patrol cars in Sri Lanka. |image2 = |alt2 = |caption2 = Police SUVs in Sri Lanka. }} '''Crime''' is present in various forms in [[Sri Lanka]]. Crime is segmented into two broad classifications: grave crimes (those which are indictable) and minor crimes (those which are not). Exceptions can be made for [[criminal liability]] on the grounds of duress, insanity, intoxication, necessity, and private defense. Punishment for crime includes several options: community service, fine, forfeiture of property, imprisonment, institutional treatment, probation, suspended sentence, whipping, and death;<ref name="Newman2010">{{cite book|last=Newman|first=Graeme R.|title=Crime and Punishment around the World: [Four Volumes]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2uK6bR9byVIC&pg=RA2-PA21|date=30 October 2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-35134-1|pages=21–}}</ref> while the death penalty is available in the country, there have been no executions since 1976.<ref name="Ghosh2013">{{cite news|last=Ghosh|first=Palash|title=Despite Wave Of Violent Crime, Sri Lanka Remains Wary About Death Penalty|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/despite-wave-violent-crime-sri-lanka-remains-wary-about-death-penalty-1220329|accessdate=12 June 2013|date=April 26, 2013|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref>
==Crimes against women and children== Sri Lanka [[Prostitution in Sri Lanka|is a participant in the prostitution industry]], and most consumers of the trade in the country are foreign travellers.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fcYq72qYRTcC&pg=PA452 |pages=452– |title=Encyclopedia of Prostitution and Sex Work |publisher=Greenwood |isbn=9780313329685 }}</ref> Nevertheless, most prostitution-related acts, such as [[human trafficking|prostitute trafficking]] and [[procuring (prostitution)|procuring]] are illegal. Prostitution has not become as severe an issue in Sri Lanka as compared to the situation in some neighbouring countries.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2004/41744.htm |title= Country Report on Human Rights Practices in Sri Lanka |publisher=State.gov |date=2008-03-11 |accessdate=2010-03-31}}</ref>
Child trafficking is a problem in Sri Lanka. Most children trafficked are treated unfairly, unwillingly and inhumanely turned into pornographic film actors or sex slaves. <ref>{{cite news|title= Sex tourists prey on Sri Lanka's children: Beach resorts are hunting-grounds for European child abusers and pornographic video makers. Tim McGirk reports from Colombo |work=[[The Independent|Independent]]|date=1994-01-19|url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/sex-tourists-prey-on-sri-lankas-children-beach-resorts-are-huntinggrounds-for-european-child-abusers-and-pornographic-video-makers-tim-mcgirk-reports-from-colombo-1407820.html|accessdate=2012-04-10|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= UN targets Lanka child sex trade |work=[[BBC]]|date=2006-07-20|url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/5197648.stm|accessdate=2012-04-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Sri Lanka to eliminate child sex tourism |work=[[Shanghai Daily]]|date=|url= http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200509/21/eng20050921_209917.html|accessdate=2012-04-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Child sex tourism spreading in Asia |work=[[CNN]]|date=|url= http://archives.cnn.com/2000/TRAVEL/NEWS/08/25/childsex.tourism.ap/index.html|accessdate=2012-04-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Child exploitation not new to stricken region |work=[[CNN]]|date=|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2005/US/01/05/child.exploitation/index.html|accessdate=2012-04-10}}</ref>
==Corruption== {{See|Corruption in Sri Lanka}}
Corruption is prevalent in Sri Lanka. Cited as "one of the most corrupt nations in the world" by Lakshman Indranath Keerthisinghe of the ''Lanka Standard'',<ref name="Lanka 1"/> there have been instances in which law enforcers take bribes from offenders who wish to have their offences waived. The government has made an effort to curb corruption in the country and a handful of corrupt individuals have been arrested and appropriately charged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.humanrights.asia/resources/journals-magazines/article2/0901/03bribery-and-corruption-control-in-sri-lanka |title=Bribery and corruption control in Sri Lanka |publisher=Asian Human Rights Commission |accessdate=June 12, 2013 }}</ref>
Corruption is considered a large expense to the Sri Lankan government.<ref name="Lanka 1">{{cite web|author=Lakshman Indranath Keerthisinghe |title=Sri Lanka one of the most corrupt nations in the world |date=October 23, 2011 |url=http://www.lankastandard.com/2011/10/sri-lanka-one-of-the-most-corrupt-nations-in-the-world/ |publisher=Lanka Standard }}</ref> However, corruption does not appear to be significant enough to pose a problem with [[foreign direct investment|foreign investment]], though it is considered to be a persistent issue with customs clearance and smuggling of some consumer products.<ref name="Ibpus2012">{{cite book|author=International Business Publications, USA|title=Sri Lanka Business Law Handbook: Strategic Information and Laws|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=43GeRBYUgJ4C&pg=PA98|date=1 January 2012|publisher=International Business Publications|isbn=978-1-4387-7107-6|pages=98–}}</ref>
==Investigation== The crime division of the Police Department of Sri Lanka has several branches. Its primary mission is to protect against all types of crimes in the country. It makes appropriate coordination with civil and military agencies, apprehends criminals, and take appropriate legal actions after the commitment of crime.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.police.lk/index.php/crime-division|title=Crime division|accessdate=19 June 2013|publisher=Sri Lanka Police}}</ref> The department also has the Police Human Rights Division which was established in 2002 with a mandate to examine and prevent human rights violations with which their officers may be charged while on duty.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.police.lk/index.php/human-rights|title= Human Rights |accessdate=19 June 2013|publisher=Sri Lanka Police}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Alleged war crimes during the final stages of the Sri Lankan Civil War]]

In [[linguistics]], '''critical language awareness''' ('''CLA''') refers to an understanding of social, political, and ideological aspects of language, linguistic variation, and discourse. It functions as a pedagogical application of a [[critical discourse analysis]] (CDA), which is a research approach that regards language as a social practice.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mosley Wetzel|first=Melissa|last2=Rogers|first2=Rebecca|date=2015-12-01|title=Constructing racial literacy through critical language awareness: A case study of a beginning literacy teacher|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0898589815000352|journal=Linguistics and Education|series=Special Issue on Critical Language Awareness Approaches in the Americas: theoretical principles, pedagogical practices and distribution of intellectual labor|volume=32, Part A|pages=27–40|doi=10.1016/j.linged.2015.03.014}}</ref> Critical language awareness as a part of language education teaches students how to analyze the language that they and others use. More specifically, critical language awareness is a consideration of how features of language such as words, grammar, and discourse choices reproduce, reinforce, or challenge certain ideologies and struggles for power and dominance.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Luke|first=Allan|date=2012-01-06|title=Critical Literacy: Foundational Notes|journal=Theory into Practice|volume=51|issue=1|pages=4–11|doi=10.1080/00405841.2012.636324|issn=0040-5841}}</ref>
Regarding linguistic variation, Fairclough argued that it is insufficient to teach students to use "appropriate" language without considering why that language is preferred and who makes that decision (as well as the implications for speakers who do not use "appropriate language").<ref>{{Cite web|title=Global capitalism and critical awareness of language|url=http://www.schools.ash.org.au/litweb/norman1.html|first=Norman|last=Fairclough|accessdate=2009-07-29|publisher=Schools on the Web|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120909092406/http://www.schools.ash.org.au/litweb/norman1.html|archivedate=2012-09-09|df=}}</ref>
CLA generally includes consideration of how a person may be marginalized by speaking a particular way, especially if that way of speaking serves as an index of their [[race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[ethnicity]], [[religion]], [[social status]], etc.
Because power is reproduced through language, CLA is "a prerequisite for effective [[democracy|democratic]] [[citizenship]], and should therefore be seen as an entitlement for citizens, especially children developing towards citizenship in the educational system".<ref>{{cite journal|author=Clark, Romy|year=1990|title=Critical Language Awareness Part I: A Critical Review of Three Current Approaches to Language Awareness.|journal=Language and Education: An International Journal|volume=4|issue=4|pages=249–60|issn=0950-0782|url=http://www.eric.ed.gov/ERICWebPortal/custom/portlets/recordDetails/detailmini.jsp?_nfpb=true&_&ERICExtSearch_SearchValue_0=EJ437787&ERICExtSearch_SearchType_0=no&accno=EJ437787|accessdate=2009-07-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Reginald Mpho Monareng|first= Rakwena |title=The Critical Language Awareness Perspective within the English Second Language Teacher Development|journal=The International Journal of the Humanities|volume=5|issue=1|pages=67–74|url=http://ijh.cgpublisher.com/product/pub.26/prod.968|accessdate=2009-07-29}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author2=Deborah Mehl|author3=Shirley Pendlebury |year=1991|title=Grey areas and open minds: critical language awareness for student teachers |journal=Journal of Curriculum Studies|volume=23|issue=5|pages=435–448|issn=1366-5839|doi=10.1080/0022027910230506|author=Mehl, Deborah}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=H. Samy Alim|year=2005|title=Critical Language Awareness in the United States: Revisiting Issues and Revising Pedagogies in a Resegregated Society |journal=Educational Researcher|volume=34|issue=7|doi=10.3102/0013189X034007024|url=http://edr.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/34/7/24|accessdate=2009-07-29|author=Alim, H. S.|pages=24–31}}</ref>
== Applications == Critical language awareness has been applied to educating students in [[South Africa]] how language was used to maintain and perpetuate the [[apartheid]] state.<ref>Janks, H. (1993). Language identity and power. Critical language awareness series. Johannesburg: Hodder and Stoughton and Wits University Press</ref>
