{{redirect|Prostitution in Ireland|Northern Ireland|Prostitution in Northern Ireland}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Life in the Republic of Ireland}} '''Prostitution in Ireland''' is legal. However, since March 2017, it has been an offence to buy sex.<ref name="enact">{{cite web|last1=Edwards|first1=Elaine|title=Minister for Justice signs new laws on sexual offences|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/minister-for-justice-signs-new-laws-on-sexual-offences-1.3026288|website=The Irish Times|accessdate=14 April 2018|date=March 27, 2017}}</ref> Third party involvement (such as operating [[brothels]], and other forms of [[pimping]]) is also illegal.<ref name="clsoa93">{{cite web|title=Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) Act, 1993|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1993/act/20/enacted/en/html|website=electronic Irish Statute Book (eISB)|language=en}}</ref> Although the 2017 law criminalising clients was designed to reduce the demand for [[prostitution]],<ref>{{cite web|last1=Farrell|first1=Alan|title=Opinion: Buying a woman's body for sexual gratification is not a harmless act|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/readme/sex-workers-in-ireland-1896233-Jan2015/|website=TheJournal.ie|accessdate=14 April 2018|language=en|date=25 January 2015}}</ref> as of 2018 the law has had little effect.<ref>{{cite web|last1=MacNamee|first1=Garreth|title=Buying sex has been illegal in Ireland for one year but 'very little' has changed|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/sex-workers-ireland-laws-3865840-Feb2018/|website=TheJournal.ie|accessdate=14 April 2018|language=en|date=23 February 2018}}</ref>
Most prostitution in [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] occurs indoors and is advertised via the Internet. [[Street prostitution]] has declined considerably.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gallagher|first1=Conor|title='It's clearly a brothel, yet nothing can be done'|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/social-affairs/it-s-clearly-a-brothel-yet-nothing-can-be-done-1.3168979|website=The Irish Times|accessdate=14 April 2018|date=29 July 2017}}</ref>
==History== === Eighteenth century === Prostitution was both highly visible and pervasive in 18th-century [[Dublin]], centred on [[Temple Bar, Dublin|Temple Bar]] and reflected the whole spectrum of [[socioeconomic class]], from street prostitutes, through organised [[brothels]] to high class courtesans, who were often illegitimate daughters of the upper class. A well known example was Margaret Leeson. The role of the prostitute in 18th-century Ireland was at least partly a product of the double standard of female sexuality. Typical of this was the way that [[venereal disease]] was constructed as being spread by prostitutes rather than their largely male clients. Irish prostitutes were frequently the victims of [[violence against women]]. Early 'rescue' campaigns emerged in this time with [[Lady Arabella Denny]] and the [[Magdalene laundries in Ireland|Magdalene Asylums]]. These provided shelter but in return expected menial labour and penitence.<ref name=Oreilly/>
=== Nineteenth century === The changing nature of Irish society following the 1801 [[Acts of Union 1800|Act of Union]] saw a redefining of the status of women, with an idealisation of [[nuns]] at one extreme and a marginalisation of prostitutes at the other. Yet it was estimated that there were 17,000 women working as prostitutes in Dublin alone, and a further 8 brothels in [[Cork (city)|Cork]]. Dublin's sex trade was largely centred on the [[Monto]] district, reputedly the largest [[red light district]] in Europe.<ref name=Oreilly/><ref>{{cite newspaper|url=http://www.independent.ie/style/sex-relationships/redlight-alert-26722484.html|title=Red-light alert|author=|date=10 April 2011|newspaper=Independent}}</ref> A major part of the demand came from the large number of [[British army]] military personnel stationed in Ireland at the time. The ‘Wrens of the Curragh’, for instance were a group of some sixty women working as ‘army camp followers’ around the [[Curragh]].<ref name=Oreilly/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.curragh.info/articles/wrens.htm|title=The Curragh Wrens|author=Con Costello|date=|website=The Curragh History Web Site|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=An outcast community:the 'wrens' of the curragh|first=Maria|last=Luddy|date=1 September 1992|journal=[[Women's History Review]]|volume=1|issue=3|pages=341–355|doi=10.1080/09612029200200014}}</ref> Increasing concern regarding venereal disease, particularly as a threat to the military led to the introduction of a series of [[Contagious Diseases Acts]] in the 1860s, enabling authorities to apprehend and detain any woman suspected of prostitution and force her to submit to examination for disease. As in many other countries opposition to the Acts, provided a rallying cry for emerging women's movements. [[Anna Haslam]] in Dublin and [[Isabella Tod]] in Belfast, both of the [[Ladies National Association for the Repeal of the Contagious Diseases Acts|Ladies National Association]], organised opposition and a recognition not only of the plight of these women but also of the root causes.<ref name=Oreilly/>
=== Twentieth century === Emerging nationalism tended to see prostitution and venereal disease as legacies of colonialism that could be resolved through independence. This movement became linked to Catholic conservatism which demanded [[social purification]] of the pure Irish soul. Thus the 1920s saw the decline of [[Monto]], as the [[Legion of Mary]] founded and led by [[Frank Duff]] successfully crusaded to close down the brothels of Monto and bring religion to the area. Prostitution continued to exist in the form of individual women selling sexual services on the streets in cities, but it was a long time before organised prostitution was seen again.<ref name=Fagan/> However, street prostitution remained intrinsically linked to the Dublin Underworld. The 1920s and 1930s witnessed a new era Church-State morality and censorship. The Magdalene Asylums became more punitive, imprisoning young women who transgressed conventional sexual morality, some for the duration of their lives, the last asylum closing only in 1996.<ref name=Oreilly/>
The Criminal Law Amendment Act 1935<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1935/en/act/pub/0006/index.html|title=Criminal Law Amendment Act 1935 (No. 6 1935)|first=|last=|date=|website=Electronic Irish Statute Book|publisher=Office of the Attorney General|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=ward/> prohibited contraception and required sex crimes cases to be tried ''in camera'', preventing media coverage and contributing to the illusion of Irish purity. In the 1950s there was much public attention around the plight of Irish women working as prostitutes in England. These were portrayed not so much as 'fallen' women, but rather as innocents lured into evil. The Women's Liberation Movement of the 1970s helped to expose the double standards. Notable was the story of [[June Levine]] who collaborated with Lyn Madden, a former Dublin sex worker for twenty years in the 70s and 80s, to write ''Lyn: A Story of Prostitution'' (1987)<ref name=Oreilly/><ref>[http://www.corkuniversitypress.com/SearchResults.asp?Search=lyn&Submit= ''Lyn: A Story of Prostitution''], by June Levine and Lyn Madden, Cork University Press (1987) {{ISBN|9780946211456}}</ref> Madden had seen her lover and pimp John Cullen firebomb the home of former sex worker and women's rights activist Dolores Lynch. Lynch perished in the fire together with her elderly mother and aunt. Madden denounced Culen and began writing the book during the ensuing trial, at which Cullen received eighteen years imprisonment. At around this time a group of street sex workers brought a successful supreme court challenge to the constitutionality of Victorian laws that required a defendant to first be identified as a common prostitute through the citing of previous convictions before conviction was possible. This successful challenge created a situation of effective decriminalisation, that also offered the women the same access to the protection of the law as anyone else. During this period prostitutes were largely independent and had a good relationship with the Gardaí. Pimping was almost unheard of, as were the other crimes previously associated with prostitution. Any suggestion of organised prostitution was limited to a small number of massage parlours in an environment where the workers were empowered to negotiate favourable terms and conditions for themselves. Also improving economic conditions and a weakening force of the Church allowed for a more visible and largely tolerated sex industry.<ref name=Oreilly/>
The Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) Act 1993,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1993/en/act/pub/0020/index.html|title=Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) Act 1993 (No. 20 1993)|first=|last=|date=|website=Electronic Irish Statute Book|publisher=Office of the Attorney General|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref> made soliciting an offence for both prostitute and customer and independent prostitution declined as the women were forced into the massage parlours to avoid arrest, where they were now disempowered by necessity and terms and conditions rapidly declined. By the late 1990s the age of the brothel, and the brothel-keeper, had truly returned. Society seemed accepting of discreet, indoor prostitution establishments and every week the mainstream entertainment magazine ''In Dublin'' ran advertisements for escort services and 'massage parlouirs' (brothels), which were usually the business operations of a small number of men and women, who knew running brothels was illegal, but were prepared to take the risk, given the massive profits involved. The magazine earned substantial revenue from these advertisements.<ref name=Oreilly/>
The blatant wealth of Ireland's brothel-keepers in the 1990s was such that the media began to take more interest.<ref name=Oreilly/> Section 23 of the Criminal Justice (Public Order) Act 1994<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1994/en/act/pub/0002/index.html|title=Criminal Justice (Public Order) Act 1994 (No. 2 1994) |first=|last=|date=|website=Electronic Irish Statute Book|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref> prohibited the advertising of brothels and prostitution and in 1999 the [[Censorship of Publications Board]] banned ''In Dublin'' magazine from carrying escort advertisements. Criminal proceedings were also brought against the magazine's publisher, Mike Hogan. The ''In Dublin'' magazine case heralded the end of escort advertising in print publications. However, the suppression of advertising had little effect as the internet and mobile phones were changing the nature of the trade. Ireland's first escort website, ''Escort Ireland'', had already established itself the previous year to take over ''In Dublin'' magazine's role.<ref name=Oreilly/>
Of note was the frequent reference to the inadequacy of the existing legislation, but there was little debate about possible alternative models.<ref name=Oreilly/> While Ireland has an international commitment to protecting the well-being of women trafficked to Ireland for the purposes of prostitution, there was little or no discussion about the rights and well-being of Irish women working in prostitution. The violent murders of prostitutes Belinda Pereira, a UK resident working for a Dublin escort agency on 28 December 1996<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/NEW+PLEA+IN+HUNT+FOR+BELINDA+KILLER%3B+Prostitute+led+double+life.-a0140189010 | title=NEW PLEA IN HUNT FOR BELINDA KILLER |author=Nicola Tallant |publisher=The Mirror |date=28 December 2005}}</ref> and Sinead Kelly<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/We+knew+prostitute+would+be+murdered+..we+told+the+gardai%3B+Hunt+for...-a060675345 | title=We knew prostitute would be murdered |author=Unknown |publisher=The Mirror |date=23 June 1998}}</ref> a young street prostitute in 1998 caused questions to be raised about the benefits of the 1993 act. Until Belinda Periera was murdered in a city centre apartment in the winter of 1996, the last murder of a prostitute while working (Dolores Lynch was murdered in her home in 1983, and seems to have no longer been working as a prostitute at the time) was in 1925 when the body of Lily O'Neill (known as "Honor Bright") was found in the Dublin Mountains.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://karlwhitney.com/dumbriffs/tag/honor-bright/ | title="Honor Bright" and "Death in a Lonely Spot" | author=Karl Whitney | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193423/http://karlwhitney.com/dumbriffs/tag/honor-bright/ | archivedate=29 October 2013 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
1999 also saw the launch of Operation Gladiator, a police operation targeting those who profit from organised prostitution. It was the first operation of its type and lasted under a year, but in that time it identified and built cases against several major Dublin brothel-keepers.<ref>{{cite book | last = Reynolds | first = Paul | title = Sex in the City: The Prostitution Racket in Ireland |year = 2003 | isbn = 978-0-7171-3688-9 | id = {{ASIN|0717136884|country=uk}} }}</ref>
=== Twenty-first century === Operation Quest was launched by the [[Gardaí]] in 2003, with the aim of tackling human trafficking, prostitution and criminality within the lap dancing industry, followed by Operation Hotel in 2005, with the aim of tackling the trafficking of females from Eastern Europe to work in the sex industry in Ireland.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.legislationline.org/download/action/download/id/1085/file/de59f69b3c816696e5b4bd04b849.pdf | title=Report on Trafficking in Human Beings |author=Equality & Law Reform and An Garda Síochána Working Group |publisher=Department of Justice |date=May 2006}}</ref> Essentially the legal framework has not changed over twenty years, but discussions about alternatives emerged in 2011 (see [[#Politics|Politics]]).
==Legal status== Prostitution itself is not an offence under Irish law. However, the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) Act of 1993 prohibits soliciting or importuning another person in a street or public place for the purpose of prostitution (this offence applies to prostitute and client). It also prohibits loitering for the purpose of prostitution, organising prostitution by controlling or directing the activities of a person in prostitution, coercing one to practice prostitution for gain, living on earnings of the prostitution of another person, and keeping a brothel or other premises for the purpose of prostitution.<ref name="clsoa93" />
Advertising brothels and prostitution is prohibited by the Criminal Justice (Public Order) Act of 1994. The minimum legal age for a prostitute in Ireland is 18 years (child prostitution legislation exists to protect persons under this age). The Criminal Law (Trafficking in Persons and Sexual Offences) Bill 2006 came into force making trafficking in persons for the purpose of their sexual exploitation a specific offence, though previous legislation already covered much of this area.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie | title=Irish Statute Book |publisher=Office of the Attorney General, Ireland}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://legislationline.org/download/action/download/id/1083/file/09056de652705d07ae75a8bf53ae.pdf | title=Criminal Law (Trafficking in Persons and Sexual Offences) Bill 2006 |publisher=Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights, Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe}}</ref><ref name="whichway" />
On 27 March 2017, the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) Act 2017 was commenced into force.<ref name="enact" /> The Act significantly amends the 1993 Act to provide that a person who pays, gives, offers or promises to pay or give a person (including a prostitute) money or any other form of remuneration or consideration for the purpose of engaging in sexual activity with a prostitute shall be guilty of an offence and shall be liable on conviction to a fine of up to €500 for a first offence, and a fine of up to €1,000 for each subsequent offence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2017/act/2/section/25/enacted/en/html#sec25|title=Amendment of Act of 1993|last=(eISB)|first=electronic Irish Statute Book|website=www.irishstatutebook.ie|language=en|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref>
== Politics == Discussion of proposed law reform became an issue in the [[Irish general election, 2011|2011 elections]], with some support from opposition parties likely to become the new Government. A group of non-government and union bodies emerged pressuring both the current government and opposition parties to abolish prostitution, by criminalising the buying of sex, along [[Prostitution in Sweden|Swedish lines]]. At the same time, those supporting the ''status quo'' or advocating a more liberal approach challenged this argument.<ref name=pressure>[http://www.independent.ie/national-news/pressure-groups-lock-horns-over-changes-to-laws-on-prostitution-2548122.html "Pressure groups lock horns over changes to laws on prostitution"], Jim Cusack, ''Irish Independent'', 20 February 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.irishcentral.com/news/Irish-Justice-Minister-in-move-to-change-laws-on-purchase-of-sex-130965203.html "Irish Justice Minister in move to change laws on purchase of sex"], Cathal Dervan, ''Irish Central'', 3 October 2011.</ref> In the ensuing [[Dáil]] election on 25 February, a new Government was formed by [[Fine Gael]] (70 seats) and [[Labour Party (Ireland)|Labour]] (34 seats). The women's branch of the Labour Party support criminalisation of purchase.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.labour.ie/download/pdf/labour_women_submission_on_the_review_of_legislation_on_prostitution_august_2012.pdf|title=Labour Women: Submission on the Review of Legislation on Prostitution|author=|date=August 2012|publisher=The Labour Party}}</ref>
In June 2012, the Department of Justice and Equality issued its ''Discussion Document on Future Direction of Prostitution Legislation''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.justice.ie/en/JELR/Pages/PB12000187|title=Discussion Document on Future Direction of Prostitution Legislation|first=|last=|date=|publisher=The Department of Justice and Equality|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref> In September 2012, the Oirechtas produced a background document entitled ''Prostitution regulation in Ireland: which way now?''<ref name=whichway/> This was followed by a conference in Dublin organised by the Department, to discuss policy alternatives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ihra.net/contents/1275|title='Ireland considering the Swedish model against prostitution? Maybe not after all' by Louise Persson|author=|date=29 October 2012|website=Harm Reduction International}}</ref> Following a request by the [[Minister for Justice and Equality]], the [[Oireachtas]] Justice Committee held hearings on discussion document between December 2012 and February 2013. Prior to the hearings, a number of the committee members, such as Independent [[Seanad Éireann|Senator]] [[Katherine Zappone]], had already committed to a sex purchase ban, and the majority of submissions and presentations supported this measure and were associated with Turn Off the Red Light.<ref name=walsh/> In June 2013, it produced a unanimous report <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/parliament/media/committees/justice/1.Part-1-final.pdf|title=Report on hearings and submissions on the Review of Legislation on Prostitution Part I|author=|date=June 2013|publisher=Joint Committee on Justice, Defence and Equality}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/parliament/media/committees/justice/Witnesses-and-Submissions-on-Review-of-Legislation-on-Prostitution.pdf|title=Joint Committee public hearings in relation to the Review of Legislation on Prostitution Part II: Witnesses & Submissions|author=|date=12 December 2012|publisher=Joint Committee on Justice, Defence and Equality}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/parliament/media/committees/justice/Committee-Debates-on-Review-of-Legislation-on-Prostitution.pdf|title=Joint Committee public hearings in relation to the Review of Legislation on Prostitution Part III: Committee Debates|author=|date=12 December 2012|publisher=Joint Committee on Justice, Defence and Equality}}</ref> recommending reform of Ireland's laws on prostitution, including criminalising purchase, and providing services for those wishing to exit prostitution.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/law-reform-will-make-prostitution-more-dangerous-272810.html|title=Law reform 'will make prostitution more dangerous'|author=Eoin English|date=21 June 2014|newspaper=Irish Examiner}}</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/letters/prostitution-and-legislation-1.1801706|title=Prostitution and legislation|author=Ronit Lentin |newspaper=Irish Times|date=20 May 2014}}</ref> Of the opposition parties, both [[Fianna Fáil]] (20 seats) and [[Sinn Féin]] (14 seats) have expressed support for this approach at their 2013 [[Ardfheiseanna]] (party conferences), with the only dissenting voices coming from the independent bloc of [[Teachtaí Dálain|deputies]] in the Dáil.<ref name=walsh/> However, there has been a reluctance on the part of the Government to act on the recommendations.<ref>{{cite newspaper|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/well-never-eradicate-prostitution-so-target-vile-trafficking-instead-29838100.html|author=James Downey|title=We'll never eradicate prostitution - so target vile trafficking instead|newspaper=Independent|date=14 December 2013}}</ref> A [[Private Member's Bill]] was however introduced in the Dáil in March 2013, the Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) (Amendment) Bill 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/viewdoc.asp?fn=/documents/bills28/bills/2013/2413/document1.htm|title=Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) (Amendment) Bill 2013 [PMB] (Number 24 of 2013) - Tithe an Oireachtais|author=|year=2013|website=Houses of the Oireachtas}}</ref> by Independent TD [[Thomas Pringle (politician)|Thomas Pringle]] which would criminalise the purchase of sex, on behalf of Turn Off the Red Light,<ref>[http://www.thomaspringle.ie/pringle-introduces-bill-criminalising-buying-sexual-services/ Pringle Introduces Bill Criminalising Buying Sexual Services], press release, Thomas Pringle TD, 13 March 2013. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906132414/http://www.thomaspringle.ie/pringle-introduces-bill-criminalising-buying-sexual-services/ |date=6 September 2014 }}</ref> which was given a [[second reading]] in May 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/debates/?id=2013-05-03a.5|title=Dáil debates – Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) (Amendment) Bill 2013: Second Stage [Private Members]|author=|date=3 May 2013|website=Kildare Street}}</ref> receiving the support of Fianna Fáil and Sinn Féin. The Government preferred to wait for the Justice Committee report, and the bill was defeated on 7 May 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie/debates+authoring/debateswebpack.nsf/takes/dail2013050700028?opendocument#AA01250|title=Criminal Law (Sexual Offences) (Amendment) Bill 2013: Second Stage (Resumed) [Private Members]|first=|last=|date=7 May 2013|website=oireachtasdebates.oireachtas.ie}}</ref>
In August 2014, former US President [[Jimmy Carter]] wrote to all Irish politicians urging the adoption of the criminalisation of the purchase of sex. Carter had been briefed by the Immigrant Council of Ireland, a leading figure in the Turn Off the Red Light campaign.<ref>[http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/jimmy-carter-calls-for-reform-of-irish-law-on-prostitution-284461.html Jimmy Carter calls for reform of Irish law on prostitution. ''Irish Examiner'' Sept 2 2014]</ref><ref>{{cite newspaper|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/letters/letters-to-the-editor-carters-intervention-over-prostitution-law-is-ill-judged-30557062.html|author=David Walsh|title=Letters to the Editor: Carter's intervention over prostitution law is ill judged|newspaper=Independent|date=3 September 2014}}</ref>
==Forms and extent of prostitution== There are no up-to-date reliable figures estimating the number of women or men currently working in prostitution in Ireland, but one estimate is 1,000.<ref name=whichway/> During Ireland's economic boom male demand for female prostitution services increased.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} There has been a marked increase in people turning towards the internet and sites as a more effective means of advertising.<ref>[http://tribune.maithu.com/archive/article/2009/jan/11/lucrative-escort-website-claims-new-owner-is-a-for/ "Lucrative 'escort' website claims new owner is a former Irish prostitute"], Ali Bracken, ''Irish Tribune'', 11 January 2009</ref>
For many years prior to the 1993 Sexual Offences Act, most female prostitutes worked on the streets, but, since this time, brothels marketed as [[escort agencies]] have been the most prevalent form of prostitution. Advertising in print publications is illegal, but a very developed Internet advertising medium exists.
Prostitutes of many nationalities now reside in Ireland and ''Ruhama'', an organisation opposed to prostitution, reported to the government in 2006 claiming that over 200 women were [[Human trafficking|trafficked]] into Ireland.<ref name=whichway/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ruhama.ie/easyedit/files/WebOireachtas%20Justice%20cmtee%20Presentation%20230506website.doc |title=Presentation to the Oireachtas Justice Committee |author=Kathleen Fahy |publisher=Ruhama |date=May 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425071018/http://www.ruhama.ie/easyedit/files/WebOireachtas%20Justice%20cmtee%20Presentation%20230506website.doc |archivedate=25 April 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.escortsurveys.com/irish_escort_clients_survey_2006.html | title=Irish Escort Clients 2006 Survey |publisher=EscortSurveys.com |date=February 2006}}</ref>
== Advocacy ==
=== Organisations === SWAI (Sex Workers Alliance Ireland), is an advocacy group for sex workers in Ireland, was formed in 2009 by an alliance of individuals and groups to promote the social inclusion, health, safety, civil rights, and the right to self-determination of sex workers. SWAI actively advocates for the decriminalisation of sex work in Ireland and believes sex workers in Ireland should be free to work in safety without fear, judgment or stigma.<ref>[http://www.sexworkersallianceireland.org/home Sex Workers Alliance Ireland] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006184049/http://www.sexworkersallianceireland.org/home |date=6 October 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/1120/1224259179202.html "Sex workers must not be viewed as victims, says group"], ''Irish Times'', 11 November 2009</ref>
Ugly Mugs Ireland is a safety scheme for sex workers established in 2009. It brings sex workers together to share information with each other about potential dangers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uglymugs.ie|title=Ugly Mugs Ireland & UK, safety for sex workers|author=|date=|website=Ugly Mugs Ireland|accessdate=12 June 2017}}</ref><ref>[http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/news/sex-workers-abused-by-men-posing-as-gardai-30804939.html "Sex workers abused by men posing as gardai"], ''Irish Independent'', 7 December 2014</ref>
Ruhama ([[Hebrew]]: Renewed life), established in 1989, is a Dublin-based NGO operated by the Catholic [[Sisters of Our Lady of Charity]] order <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.urban75.net/forums/threads/trustees-of-irish-anti-prostitution-ngo-ruhama-used-to-run-magdelene-laundries.300985/|title=Trustees of Irish anti-prostitution NGO Ruhama used to run Magdelene Laundries|author=|date=|website=urban75.net}}</ref> which works on a national level with women affected by prostitution and other forms of commercial sexual exploitation. The organisation regards prostitution as violence against women and violations of women's human rights. Ruhama sees prostitution and the social and cultural attitudes which sustain it as being deeply rooted in gender inequality and social marginalisation. Ruhama offers a range of services to support women in and exiting prostitution. Ruhama also seeks to highlight sex trafficking.<ref>[http://www.ruhama.ie/ Ruhama website], retrieved 3 September 2013.</ref><ref>[http://www.thejournal.ie/ruhama-reports-18-per-cent-increase-in-demand-for-support-services-567797-Aug2012/ "Ruhama reports 18 per cent increase in demand for support services"], ''The Journal.ie'', 22 August 2012.</ref>
=== Campaigns === A campaign set up in 2011 to end prostitution and sex trafficking in Ireland called "Turn Off the Red Light" is run by an alliance of more than 66 community, union and religious groups,<ref>[http://www.turnofftheredlight.ie/ Turn Off the Red Light], website</ref><ref>[http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0202/prostitution.html "Group calls for reform of prostitution laws"], RTÉ News / Ireland, 2 February 2011</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110214042236/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2011/0203/1224288890630.html "Prominent Irishmen seek change to prostitution laws"], Connor Lally, ''Irish Times'', 3 February 2011</ref> including the [[Irish Nurses and Midwives Organisation]],<ref>[http://southdublin.today.ie/2014/06/26/news-inmo-prostitution/ Irish Nurses and Midwives Organisation. Irish Nurses call for new prostitution laws in Ireland 2014] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140712115632/http://southdublin.today.ie/2014/06/26/news-inmo-prostitution/ |date=12 July 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.inmo.ie/Home/Index/7640/10204|title=Social Policy - Prostitution – target the real criminals|author=Clare Treacy|date=5 September 2014|website=archive.org|deadurl=|archiveurl=|archivedate=|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and the [[Irish Medical Organisation]]. Core members are the Immigrant Council, Ruhama and the [[National Women's Council of Ireland|National Women's Council]].
In response, a counter-campaign called "Turn Off the Blue Light" was created by sex workers and supporters in favour of decriminalisation to rebut what they see as misleading information and to present a positive image of sex workers in Ireland. A chief complaint it has of the "Turn Off The Red Light" campaign is that it conflates legal and consensual sex work with illegal human trafficking.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110509035132/http://www.turnoffthebluelight.ie/ Turn Off the Blue Light], website</ref><ref>[http://www.humanrights.ie/index.php/2011/05/01/international-workers-day-and-the-labour-rights-of-women/ "International Workers Day and the Labour Rights of Women"], Máiréad Enright, Human Rights in Ireland</ref>

[[File:Repinskaja-2007.jpg|thumb|Hotel Repinskaya in Repino]]
'''Repino''' ({{lang-ru|Ре́пино}}) is an [[administrative divisions of Saint Petersburg|area]] of [[Saint Petersburg]], [[Russia]], and a station of the [[Saint Petersburg-Vyborg railroad]]. It was known by its Finnish name '''Kuokkala''' until 1948, when it was renamed after its most famous inhabitant, the painter [[Ilya Repin]]. It is {{convert|30|km|sp=us}} northwest of St. Petersburg<ref name="Pb-Aktuell">[http://www.petersburg.aktuell.ru/petersburg/sehenswert/ausflug/repino_zu_gast_beim_grossen_meister_9.html {{de icon}} Petersburg-Aktuell, "Repino: Zu Gast beim großen Meister"], retrieved on 25 May 2007.</ref> on the [[Karelian Isthmus]] and [[Gulf of Finland]]. The population was 2,478 at the 2010 Census.
==History==
The first mention of Kuokkala is in a peace treaty between the Republic of Novgorod and Sweden in 1323. The territory where the village is located was fought over between the Muscovites and Swedes in the 16th and 17th centuries and came under Russian control after the Great Northern War in early 18th Century. The village was inhabited by fishermen of Finnish and Russian ethnicities. The area developed further after 1870 when the [[Riihimäki–Saint Petersburg railway|railway linking St Petersburg and Helsinki]] passed through the town. Wealthier residents of St Peterburg built holiday villas in the area and a new railway station was built in 1889. Kuokkala was located in the [[Grand Duchy of Finland]], a self-governing part of the [[Russian Empire]], which had a more liberal environment, attracting artists and intellectuals including the artist [[Ilya Repin]]. [[Lenin]] spent some time in Kuokkala during 1905 to 1907, staying at the Vasa Villa.
Shortly after the [[October Revolution]] in 1917, [[Finland]] declared its independence from the [[Soviet Union]] and Kuokkala became part of the new independent nation while retaining a significant ethnic Russian population. There was a skirmish between White and Red Finns at Kuokkala during the [[Finnish Civil War]] on 28 April 1918. Kuokkala was taken over by the Soviets when the [[Karelian Isthmus]] was ceded by Finland to the [[Soviet Union]] after the [[Winter War]] and the [[Continuation War]] (1939–1944). Kuokkala became a part of the Leningrad Oblast in 1948 and was renamed Repino in memory of the [[Painting|painter]] [[Ilya Repin]].<ref name="Pb-Aktuell"/>. After the war, the area was developed as a tourist area with several hotels and sanatoriums and was transferred to the jurisdiction of the city of St Petersburg as part of the [[Kurortny District]]
==Penates== [[File:Repino100.jpg|thumb|Ilya Repin's home called "Penates"]]
In 1899, Repin bought an estate here and called it ''Penaty'' ({{lang-ru|Пенаты}}, meaning [[Penates]], [[Roman Empire|Roman]] [[household deity|household deities]]). He designed his own house, and after it had been built several years later, Repin moved to Kuokkala. He would live there until his death in 1930. The house is surrounded by a large park.
The estate is part of the [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] ''Saint Petersburg and Related Groups of Monuments''.<ref>[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/540/multiple=1&unique_number=635 Unesco World Heritage Site ''Saint Petersburg and Related Groups of Monuments''], retrieved 25 May 2007.</ref> The estate has been a museum since 1940.<ref>[http://www.russianmuseums.info/M267 Info on the museum "Penates"], retrieved 25 May 2007.</ref>
==Famous inhabitants== *[[Mikhail Botvinnik]], World [[chess]] champion, was born in Kuokkala in 1911. *[[Vladimir Lenin]], Russian Communist leader and founder of the USSR, lived in Kuokkala between 1906 and 1907. *[[Ivan Puni]], [[Russian avant-garde|avant-garde]] artist, was born in Kuokkala in 1894. *[[Ilya Repin]], painter and sculptor, lived in Kuokkala from the beginning of the 20th century until his death in 1930. *[[Korney Chukovsky]], children's poet and philologist, lived in Kuokkala from 1906 till 1916. *[[Elena Mrozovskaya]], an early female photographer, died in Kuokkala in 1941.<ref>{{citation|title=A moving river of tears: Russia's experience in Finland|volume=15|series=American university studies: Slavic languages and literature|first=Temira|last=Pachmuss|publisher=P. Lang|year=1992|isbn=9780820419565|quotation=Elena Lukinichna Mrozovskaya, an artistic photographer in St. Petersburg, had a house in Vammelsuu in the 1920s; in 1941 she died in Kuokkala, after the Soviet-Finnish War of 1939-40.|page=173}}</ref> *[[Dmitri Shostakovich]], Soviet composer, went to Cottage #20 at the Composers' Union Resort, located in Repino, to relax and compose, every year from 1961 to 1975.<ref>http://www.katyachilingiri.com/shostakovich.html</ref> *In 2018, Repino was the base for the [[England national football team|England team]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] that was held in Russia.

{{Infobox film | name = The Dancing Boys of Afghanistan | image = Dancing-Boys-of-Afghanistan-documentary.jpg | caption = | director = [[Najibullah Quraishi]] | producer = [[Jamie Doran]] | writer = Jamie Doran | narrator = | starring = | music = | cinematography = Mike Healy | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|2010|3|29}} | runtime = 52 minutes | country = | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''The Dancing Boys of Afghanistan''''' is a 2010 documentary film produced by Clover Films and directed by Afghan [[journalist]] [[Najibullah Quraishi]] about the practice of ''[[bacha bazi]]'' in [[Afghanistan]]. The 52-minute documentary premiered in the UK at the [[Royal Society of Arts]] on March 29, 2010<ref name="arts">[http://www.thersa.org/events/audio-and-past-events/2010/true-stories-the-dancing-boys-of-afghanistan "True Stories: The Dancing Boys of Afghanistan"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100831101441/http://www.thersa.org/events/audio-and-past-events/2010/true-stories-the-dancing-boys-of-afghanistan |date=2010-08-31 }}, ''Royal Society of Arts'', screening 29 March 2010; 18:30</ref> and aired on ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|PBS Frontline]]'' in the United States on April 20.
''Bacha bazi'', also known as ''bacchá'' (from the [[Persian language|Persian]] ''bacheh'' بچه‌), literally "playing with boys" in Persian, [[Pashto language|Pashto]] and [[Hindi-Urdu]]), is a form of [[sexual slavery]] and [[child prostitution]]<ref>[http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/246409/Boys_in_Afghanistan_Sold_Into_Prostitution_Sexual_Slavery "Boys in Afghanistan Sold Into Prostitution, Sexual Slavery"], ''Digital Journal'', Nov 20, 2007</ref> in which [[prepubescent]] and adolescent boys are sold to wealthy or powerful men for entertainment and sexual activities. This business thrives in [[Afghanistan]], where many men keep dancing boys as status symbols. The practice is illegal under Afghan law.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/dancingboys/view/|title=The Dancing Boys of Afghanistan|website=PBS|date=April 20, 2010|accessdate=October 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2010-02-22/the-warlords-tune-afghanistans-war-on-children/338920|title=The Warlord's Tune: Afghanistan's war on children|last1=Bannerman|first1=Mark|website=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=October 16, 2014}}</ref>
==Notes== *[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/sep/12/dancing-boys-afghanistan Ghaith Abdul-Ahad: The dancing boys of Afghanistan] (''[[The Guardian]]'') *[http://www.popmatters.com/pm/review/124334-frontline-the-dancing-boys-of-afghanistan Cynthia Fuchs: Frontline: The Dancing Boys of Afghanistan] (PopMatters.com) *[http://www.illumemagazine.com/zine/articleDetail.php?The-Dancing-Boys-of-Afghanistan-13290 Jeremy Anderson: The Dancing Boys of Afghanistan] (Illume.com)

'''The Distinguished Scholarship Award''' is given by the [[Pacific Sociological Association]] (PSA) to sociologists based in the Pacific region of North America, in recognition of major scholarly contributions.<ref>[http://calsociology.blogspot.com/2012/10/the-pacific-sociological-association.html UC Berkeley FAR Sociology. Accessed 22 December 2013.]</ref> To be eligible for the award, a sociologist's contribution must be embodied in a recently published book or through a series of articles with a common theme.<ref>[http://pacificsoc.org/awards-committee.html PSA Awards Committee and Awards Information. Accessed 22 December 2013.]</ref>
== Recipients == The Distinguished Scholarship Award was created by the PSA in 1984. The award was given biennially until 1990, when it became an annually granted award.<ref>[http://pacificsoc.org/past-award-recipients.html PSA Past Award Recipients. Accessed 22 December 2013.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006113443/http://pacificsoc.org/past-award-recipients.html |date=6 October 2014 }}</ref> *2015 - Paul Almeida, [[University of California, Merced]]: ''Mobilizing Democracy: Globalization and Citizen Protest'' *2014 - Isaac William Martin, University of California, San Diego: ''Rich People’s Movements: Grassroots Campaigns to Untax the One Percent'' *2013 - [[Drew Halfmann]], [[University of California, Davis]]: ''Doctors and Demonstrators: How Political Institutions Shape Abortion Law in the United States, Britain, and Canada'' *2012 - Cecilia Menjivar, [[Arizona State University]]: ''Enduring Violence: Latino Women's Lives in Guatemala'' *2011 - Julie Shayne, [[University of Washington Bothell]] and [[University of Washington Seattle]]: ''They Used to Call Us Witches: Chilean Exiles, Culture, and Feminism'' *2010 - Kimberly Richman, [[University of San Francisco]]: ''Courting Change: Queer Parents, Judges, and the Transformation of American Family Law'' *2009 - Edward Telles and Vilma Ortiz, [[University of California Los Angeles]]: ''Generations of Exclusion: Mexican Americans, Assimilation, and Race'' *2008 - Ivan Light, [[University of California Los Angeles]]: ''Deflecting Immigration: Networks, Markets and regulation in Los Angeles'' *2007 - [[Jerome Karabel]], [[University of California Berkeley]]: ''The Chosen: The Hidden History of Admission and Exclusion at Harvard, Yale, and Princeton'' *2006 - [[John Foran (sociologist)|John Foran]], [[University of California Santa Barbara]]: ''Taking Power: On the Origins of Third World Revolutions'' and Paul Lichterman, [[University of Southern California]]: ''Elusive Togetherness: Church Groups Trying to Bridge America’s Divisions'' *2005 - No award given *2004 - [[Evelyn Nakano Glenn]], [[University of California Berkeley]]: ''Unequal Freedom: How Race and Gender Shaped American Citizens'' and Laura Grindstaff, [[University of California Davis]]: ''The Money Shot: Trash, Class, and the Making of TV Talk Shows'' *2003 - Amy Binder, [[University of California, San Diego]]: ''Contentious Curricula: Afrocentrism and Creationism in American Public Schools'' *2002 - Pierrett Hondagneu-Sotelo, [[University of Southern California]]: ''Domestica: Immigrant Workers Cleaning and Caring in the Shadows of Affluence'' *2001 - Valerie Jeness, [[University of California Irvine]] for a series of published articles dealing with hate-crimes, hate-crime legislation, and community responses to hate-motivated violence. The series was published in the following journals between 1994-1998: ''Gender and Society'', ''Social Problems'', ''Sociological Perspectives'', ''Research in Social Movements'', ''Conflict and Change'', and the ''American Sociological Review''. *2000 - Charles Varano: ''Forced Choices: Class, Community, and Worker Ownership'' *1999 - [[William Domhoff]]: ''Who Rules America? Power and Politics in the Year 2000'' *1998 - Simonetta Falasca-Zamponi: ''Fascist Spectacle: The Aesthetics of Power in Mussolini's Italy'' *1997 - Calvin Morrill: ''The Executive Way : Conflict Management in Corporations'' *1996 - James Aho: ''This Thing of Darkness: The Sociology of the Enemy'' *1995 - [[John Foran (sociologist)|John Foran]]: ''Fragile Resistance'' *1994 - [[David A. Snow]] and Leon Anderson, ''Down on Their Luck: A Study of Homeless Street People'' *1993 - [[Rodney Stark]] and [[William Sims Bainbridge]]: ''A Theory of Religion'' *1992 - Kathy Charmaz: "Good Days, Bad Days, The Self in Chronic Illness and Time" *1991 - George M. Thomas: "Revivalism and Cultural Change: Christianity, Nation Building, and the Market in 19th-Century United States" *1990 - Jack Katz: ''Seductions of Crime: Moral and Sensual Attraction to Doing Evil'' *1988 - Unknown or No award given *1986 - [[Claude S. Fischer]]: ''To Dwell Among Friends: Personal Networks in Town and City'' *1984 - No award given

{{EngvarB|date=March 2017}} {{Use Bangladeshi English|date=August 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox women |image = Begum Rokeya.jpg |caption = [[Begum Rokeya]] was a pioneer writer and a social worker of the undivided [[Bengal]]. She is most famous for her efforts in favour of [[gender equality]] and other social issues. |gii = 0.518 (2012) |gii_rank = 107th<ref name="UN">{{cite web |url=http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr14-report-en-1.pdf|title=Human Development Report 2014|publisher=The United Nations |accessdate=24 July 2014}}</ref> |matdeath = 240 (2010) |womparl = 19.7% (2012) |femed = 30.8% (2010) |womlab = 57.2% (2011) | ggg = 0.6848 (2013) | ggg_rank = 75th | ggg_ref =<ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} The status of '''women in Bangladesh''' has been subject to many important changes over the past few centuries. The [[Bangladeshi]] women have made significant progress since the country gained its independence in 1971. The past four decades have seen increased political empowerment for women, better job prospects, increased opportunities of education and the adoption of new laws to protect their rights though Bangladesh's policies regarding women's rights is influenced by [[patriarchy|patriarchal values]].<ref name="Patriarchy in Bangladesh">{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/law-rights/2017/05/21/patriarchy-kamla-bahsin-obr|title=Patriarchy: The deep rooted cultural beliefs that normalise rape|website=[[Dhaka Tribune]]}}</ref> {{As of|2018}}, the [[Prime Minister of Bangladesh]], the [[Speaker of Jatiyo Shangshad|Speaker of Parliament]], the [[Leader of the Opposition (Bangladesh)|Leader of the Opposition]] were women. Bangladesh has also not elected a male as Prime Minister [[Bangladeshi general election, 1988|since 1988]].
==History== {{Expert needed|Bangladesh|section|reason=rewrite and update needed on Pre- and post independence era|date= September 2018}} Available data on health, nutrition, education, and economic performance indicated that in the 1980s the status of '''women in [[Bangladesh]]''' remained considerably inferior to that of men. Women, in custom and practice, remained subordinate to men in almost all aspects of their lives; greater autonomy was the privilege of the rich or the necessity of the very poor.
Most women's lives remained centred on their traditional roles, and they had limited access to [[market (place)|market]]s, [[productive services]], education, health care, and local government. This lack of opportunities contributed to high fertility patterns, which diminished family well-being, contributed to the malnourishment and generally poor health of children, and frustrated educational and other national development goals. In fact, acute poverty at the margin appeared to be hitting hardest at women. As long as women's access to health care, education, and training remained limited, prospects for improved productivity among the female population remained poor.
About 82 percent of women lived in rural areas in the late 1980s. The majority of rural women, perhaps 70 percent, were in small cultivator, tenant, and landless households; many worked as labourers part-time or seasonally, usually in post-harvest activities, and received payment in kind or in meager cash wages. Another 20 percent, mostly in poor landless households, depended on casual labour, gleaning, begging, and other irregular sources of income; typically, their income was essential to household survival. The remaining 10 percent of women were in households mainly in the professional, trading, or large-scale landowning categories, and they usually did not work outside the home.
The economic contribution of women was substantial but largely unacknowledged. Women in rural areas were responsible for most of the post-harvest work, which was done in the [[Kitchen|chula]], and for keeping livestock, poultry, and small gardens. Women in cities relied on domestic and traditional jobs, but in the 1980s they increasingly worked in manufacturing jobs, especially in the readymade garment industry. Those with more education worked in government, health care, and teaching, but their numbers remained very small. Continuing high rates of population growth and the declining availability of work based in the chula meant that more women sought employment outside the home. Accordingly, the female labour force participation rate doubled between 1974 and 1984, when it reached nearly 8 percent. Female wage rates in the 1980s were low, typically ranging between 20 and 30 percent of male wage rates.
The official religion of Bangladesh is Islam with over 90% of the population being Muslim.<ref name=census2011>{{cite web|url=http://203.112.218.65/WebTestApplication/userfiles/Image/National%20Reports/Union%20Statistics.pdf |title= Official Census Results 2011 page xiii |publisher=Bangladesh Government|date= |accessdate=2015-04-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/03/bangladesh-court-upholds-islam-religion-state-160328112919301.html|title=Bangladesh court upholds Islam as religion of the state|website=www.aljazeera.com}}</ref>
==Education and economic development==
===Education=== {{Further information|Education in Bangladesh}} [[File:Azimpur Girls' School 1.JPG|thumb|200 px|Azimpur Girls' School in Bangladesh]] The [[literacy rate]] in Bangladesh is lower for females (55.1%) compared to males (62.5%) – 2012 estimates for population aged 15 and over.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/Library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2103.html|title=The World Factbook|website=www.cia.gov|access-date=2 August 2016}}</ref>
During the past decades, Bangladesh has improved its education policies; and the access of girls to education has increased. In the 1990s, girls' enrolment in primary school has increased rapidly. Although there is now gender parity in enrolments at the primary and lower secondary school level, the percentage of girls drops in the later secondary school years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unicef.org/bangladesh/education.html|title=UNICEF Bangladesh – Girls' Education – Girls' Education Strategy for Bangladesh|website=www.unicef.org|access-date=2 August 2016}}</ref>
===Workforce participation=== Women in Bangladesh are engaged in many work activities, from domestic work inside the home, to outside paid work. Women's work is often undervalued and under-reported.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/genderInstitute/about/resourcesNailaKabeer/mahmudAndTasneemTheUnderreportingOfWomensEconomicActivity.pdf|title=Department of Gender Studies|first=London School of Economics and Political|last=Science|publisher=}}</ref>
===Land and property rights=== Women's [[inheritance]] rights are poor: discriminatory laws and patriarchal social norms make it difficult for many women to have access to land.<ref name="ohchr.org">http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/HRBodies/CEDAW/RuralWomen/CDABangladesh.pdf</ref> Most women inherit according to the local interpretations of [[Sharia Law]].<ref name="ohchr.org"/>
==Crimes against women==
===Rape=== {{see also|Chittagong Hill Tracts conflict|Persecution of Buddhists}}
Bengali settlers and soldiers in the [[Chittagong Hill Tracts]] have raped native [[Jumma people|Jumma]] ([[Chakma people|Chakma]]) women "with impunity" with the Bangladeshi security forces doing little to protect the Jummas and instead assisting the rapists and settlers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.survivalinternational.org/news/10141 |title=Chittagong Hill Tracts of Bangladesh – rapists act with impunity |last1=McEvoy |first1=Mark |last2= |first2= |date= 3 April 2014 |website=Survival International – The movement for tribal peoples |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>
The indigenous Buddhist and Hindu Jummas of Sino-Tibetan background have been targeted by the Bangladeshi government with massive amounts of violence and genocidal policies as ethnic Bengali settlers swarmed into Jumma lands, seized control and massacred them with the Bangladeshi military engaging in mass rape of women, massacres of entire villages and attacks on Hindu and Buddhist religious sites with deliberate targeting of monks and nuns.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marxist.com/fate-chittagong-hill-tracts-tribes-bangladesh.htm |title=The fate of the Chittagong Hill Tracts tribes of Bangladesh |last1=Iqbal |first1=Jamil M. |last2= |first2= |date= 2 November 2009 |website= In Defence of Marxism |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>
In Bangladesh's rural areas rape has been committed by 1/8th of the men.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://news.vice.com/video/bangladeshi-gang-rape |title=Bangladeshi Gang Rape |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date=21 November 2014 |website=Vice News |publisher= |access-date= |quote=}}</ref>
===Child marriage=== Bangladesh has one of the highest rates of [[child marriage]] in the world.<ref>http://www.unicef.org/sowc09/docs/SOWC09-CountryExample-Mali.pdf</ref> The practice of [[dowry]], although illegal, contributes to this phenomenon.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.unicef.org/bangladesh/children_4866.htm |title=Early marriage |publisher=UNICEF |accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref> 29% of girls get married before age 15 and 65% before the age of 18.<ref name=HRW/> Government action has had little effect, and has been contradictory: although the government has pledged to end child marriage by 2041, the Prime Minister in 2015 attempted to lower the age of marriage for girls from 18 to 16.<ref name=HRW>{{citation |url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/06/09/bangladesh-girls-damaged-child-marriage |title=Bangladesh: Girls Damaged by Child Marriage: Stop Plan to Lower Marriage Age to 16 |publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=9 June 2015 |accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref> An exception to the law was instituted so that marriage at 16 is permitted with parental consent.<ref>{{citation |url=http://en.prothom-alo.com/bangladesh/news/60481/Age-of-marriage-18-but-16-with-parental-consent |title=Age of marriage 18, but 16 with parental consent |publisher=Prothom Alo |author=Mansura Hossain |date=7 March 2015 |accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref>
===Domestic violence=== In 2010, Bangladesh enacted the ''Domestic Violence (Prevention and Protection) Act, 2010''.<ref>http://phrplanbd.org/attachments/article/42/DV%20Act_Engling%20Translation%20%28unofficial%29.pdf</ref> Domestic violence (DV) is accepted by a significant percentage of the population: in the 2011 [[Demographic and Health Surveys|DHS survey]], 32.5% of women said that a husband is justified in hitting or beating his wife for specific reasons (the most common reason given was if the wife "argues with him" – at 22.4%).<ref>http://dhsprogram.com/pubs/pdf/FR265/FR265.pdf</ref> In recent years violence towards women, committed by men, has decreased significantly and is considerably low compared to south Asian countries like Sri Lanka, Nepal, and India.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/57-of-boys-53-of-girls-think-wife-beating-is-justified/articleshow/12862006.cms|title=57% of boys, 53% of girls think wife beating is justified – Times of India|access-date=2 August 2016}}</ref> Violence towards women is a crime. Awareness needs to be raised to uphold women's human rights.
===Dowry=== Dowry violence is a problem in Bangladesh. The country has taken action against the practice of dowry through laws such as ''Dowry Prohibition Act, 1980''; ''Dowry Prohibition (Amendment) Ordinance, 1982''; and ''Dowry Prohibition (Amendment) Ordinance, 1986''. However, abuses regarding dowry continue, with the legal enforcement against dowry being weak.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/86100/bangladesh-dowry-violence-continues-unabated|title=Dowry violence continues unabated|date=11 September 2009|publisher=}}</ref>
===Sexual harassment=== {{Further information|Sexual harassment|Eve teasing}} ''Eve-teasing'' is a [[euphemism]] used throughout South Asia, in countries such as Pakistan,<ref>{{cite news| url= http://tribune.com.pk/story/572526/eve-teasing-the-power-game/ |title= Eve teasing: The power game| work= The Express Tribune |location= Pakistan | first= Tehniya S |last= Afridi |date= 8 July 2013 |accessdate= 9 February 2015 }}</ref> India and Bangladesh,<ref>[http://www.thedailystar.net/eve-teasers-beat-dead-youth-in-dhaka-45137 "Eve-teasers beat dead youth in Dhaka"], ''[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|Daily Star]]'', 11 October 2014.</ref> for public [[sexual harassment]] or [[Sexual assault|molestation]] (often known as "[[street harassment]]") of women by men, where [[Eve]] alludes to the very first woman, according to the Biblical [[creation story]].<ref>{{citation| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Fn-Sh1nv7pQC&pg=PA109&dq=eve-teasing |title= Eve Teasing |work= The Official Dictionary of Unofficial English |first= Grant |last= Barrett |publisher= McGraw-Hill Professional |year= 2006 |isbn= 0-07-145804-2 |page= 109}}</ref> Sexual harassment affects many women in Bangladesh, especially teenage girls, where the girls are intimidated in the streets, are shouted obscenities at, laughed at, or grabbed by their clothes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/91356/bangladesh-when-sexual-harassment-leads-to-suicide|title=When sexual harassment leads to suicide|date=13 December 2010|access-date=2 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/bangladesh/law-rights/2018/03/08/sexual-harassment-solution-gender-literacy-mindset|title=Sexual harassment: Solution lies with gender literacy, changing patriarchal mindset|website=[[Dhaka Tribune]]}}</ref> As Bangladeshi society is conservative, girls and women show negative attitudes towards sexuality.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dhakatribune.com/uncategorized/2014/05/05/are-we-ready-for-sex-ed|title=Are we ready for sex ed?|website=[[Dhaka Tribune]]}}</ref>
==Other concerns== ===Freedom of movement=== Bangladeshi women and girls don't get the rights of [[freedom of movement]] everywhere as the men have, the society is based on patriarchal values and [[social conservatism|socially conservative]] policies towards women and girl's freedom.<ref name="Patriarchy in Bangladesh"/>
===Health=== The [[maternal mortality rate]] in Bangladesh is 240 deaths/100,000 live births (as of 2010).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2223rank.html|title=The World Factbook|website=www.cia.gov|access-date=2 August 2016}}</ref> [[Sexually transmitted infections]] are relatively common,<ref>{{cite journal | pmc = 1744386 | pmid=11588280 | volume=77 | title=Prevalence of infectious diseases in Bangladeshi women living adjacent to a truck stand: HIV/STD/hepatitis/genital tract infections | year=2001 | journal=Sex Transm Infect | pages=344–50 | last1 = Gibney | first1 = L | last2 = Macaluso | first2 = M | last3 = Kirk | first3 = K | last4 = Hassan | first4 = MS | last5 = Schwebke | first5 = J | last6 = Vermund | first6 = SH | last7 = Choudhury | first7 = P | doi=10.1136/sti.77.5.344}}</ref> although the rate of [[HIV/AIDS]] is low.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2155rank.html|title=The World Factbook|website=www.cia.gov|access-date=2 August 2016}}</ref> A 2014 study found that Bangladeshi women' knowledge about different diseases is very poor.<ref>http://www.biomedcentral.com/content/pdf/1471-2458-14-775.pdf</ref> Bangladesh has recently expanded training programs of midwives to improve reproductive health and outcomes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/features/2014/midwifes-bangladesh/en/|title=WHO - Bangladesh expands training of midwives to improve maternal and neonatal health|website=www.who.int}}</ref>
===Family planning=== Already in the 1990s, [[family planning]] was recognised as very important in Bangladesh.<ref>http://dspace.icddrb.org/dspace/bitstream/123456789/2561/1/Bangladesh+family+planning+programme,lesson+learned+and+direction+for+the+future,+monograph+6.pdf</ref> The [[total fertility rate]] (TFR) is 2.45 children born/woman (estimates as of 2014).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/rankorder/2127rank.html|title=The World Factbook|website=www.cia.gov|access-date=2 August 2016}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery widths="240px" heights="180"> Image:21 Feb 1953 Dhaka University female students procession.png|Bangladeshi women form up a rally at the first anniversary of [[Bengali Language Movement]] in [[Dhaka University]] in 1953. Image:Germents worker Bangladesh.jpg|Women make up most of the workforce of Bangladesh's [[Bangladesh textile industry|export oriented garment industry]] that makes the highest contribution to the country's [[Economy of Bangladesh|economic growth]].<ref name=BILA>{{cite report|publisher=Bureau of International Labor Affairs|url=http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/sweat/bangladesh.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040219181233/http://www.dol.gov/ilab/media/reports/iclp/sweat/bangladesh.htm|archive-date=February 19, 2004|dead-url=yes|title=Bangladesh}} </ref>

{{Infobox women by region | image = Two Muslim women in tudungs at an engagement party, Brunei - 20100531.jpg | caption = Two Bruneian women | gii = <!-- Gender Inequality Index, value and year, e.g. "0.610 (2012)" --> | gii_rank = <!-- Gender Inequality Index, rank --> | matdeath = <!-- Maternal mortality rate, per 100,000 --> | womparl = <!-- Women in national parliament, percent --> | femed = <!-- Females over 25 with secondary education, percent --> | womlab = <!-- Women in labour force, percent --> | ggg = 0.6730 (2013) | ggg_rank = 88th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} [[File:Pengiran Anak Sarah army cadet.png|thumb|right|Pengiran Anak Sarah (Crown Princess of Brunei) in her army cadet uniform in 2009.]] {{Women in society sidebar}} '''Women in Brunei''' are women living in [[Brunei Darussalam]]. In their version of Islamic society, Bruneian women are regarded as persons of "very high status".<ref name="EC">{{Cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/Bo-Co/Brunei-Darussalam.html#b#ixzz2VlCLVy2y|title=Culture of Brunei Darussalam - history, people, traditions, women, beliefs, food, customs, family, social|website=www.everyculture.com|access-date=2017-06-25}}</ref>
The U.S. Department of State has stated that discrimination against women is a problem in Brunei.<ref name="state.gov">[https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2010/eap/154379.htm 2010 Human Rights Report: Brunei Darussalam]</ref>
==Legal rights== {{Citation needed span|text=The law prohibits sexual harassment and stipulates that whoever assaults or uses criminal force, intending thereby to outrage or knowing it is likely to outrage the modesty of a person, shall be punished with imprisonment for as much as five years and [[Caning in Brunei|caning]]. The law stipulates imprisonment of up to 30 years, and caning with not fewer than 12 strokes for rape. The law does not criminalise spousal rape; it explicitly states that sexual intercourse by a man with his wife, as long as she is not under 13 years of age, is not rape. Protections against sexual assault by a spouse are provided under the amended Islamic Family Law Order 2010 and Married Women Act Order 2010. The penalty for breaching a protection order is a fine not exceeding BN$2,000 ($1,538) or imprisonment not exceeding six months.
There is no specific domestic violence law, but arrests have been made in domestic violence cases under the Women and Girls Protection Act. The police investigate domestic violence only in response to a report by a victim. The police were generally responsive in the investigation of such cases. The criminal penalty for a minor domestic assault is one to two weeks in jail and a fine. An assault resulting in serious injury is punishable by caning and a longer prison sentence.
A special unit staffed by female officers has been established within the police department to investigate domestic abuse and child abuse complaints. A hotline was available for persons to report domestic violence. The Ministry of Culture, Youth, and Sport's Department of Community Development provides counselling for women and their spouses. Based on individual circumstances, some female and minor victims were placed in protective custody while waiting for their cases to be brought to court. Islamic courts staffed by male and female officials offered counselling to married couples in domestic violence cases. Officials did not encourage wives to reconcile with flagrantly abusive spouses. Islamic courts recognise assault as grounds for divorce.
Couples and individuals have the right to decide the number, spacing, and timing of their children, and have access to contraceptive devices and methods through the government and private clinics. According to information gathered by the UN, in 2008 the maternal mortality rate was an estimated 21 deaths per 100,000 live births. Citizens enjoy free medical and health care, including skilled attendance during childbirth, prenatal care, and essential obstetric and postpartum care. Women had equal access to diagnostic and treatment facilities for [[sexually transmitted diseases]]. Women had equal access to [[HIV]] treatment and counselling, as well as follow-up treatment.
In accordance with the government's interpretation of Qur'anic precepts, Muslim women have rights similar to those of Muslim men in areas such as divorce and child custody. Islamic law requires that males receive twice the inheritance of women. Civil law permits female citizens to pass their nationality on to their children and to own property and other assets, including business properties. Women with permanent positions in the government can now apply for travel allowances for their children. They cannot do so for husbands working in the private sector. With this exception, they receive the same allowance privileges as their college-educated male counterparts. According to government statistics, women made up 57 percent of the civil service force and held 28 percent of senior management posts. Women are not discriminated against in access to employment and business.|date=June 2017|reason=}}
=== Reproductive rights === {{Main|Abortion in Brunei}} [[Abortion]] in Brunei is largely illegal, with an exception if a woman's life is danger. Previously, the penalty for receiving an abortion was up to seven years in prison, with 10-15 years for the person performing the abortion.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/population/abortion/Brunei.abo.htm|title=Brunei abortion penal code|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hsph.harvard.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-25}}</ref><ref name=UN>{{cite book | title=Abortion Policies: A Global Review | url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion/ | chapter=Brunei Darussalam | chapterurl=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/abortion/doc/brunei1.doc | deadurl=no | year=2002 | publisher=United Nations Population Division | volume=Country Profiles | format=DOC | accessdate=14 March 2017 }}</ref> In 2014, Brunei's government implemented [[Sharia]] criminal law in a series of phases which was set to increase the punishment for abortion to execution by [[stoning]].<ref name="beverly hills">{{cite news|last1=Cohen|first1=Sandy|title=Beverly Hills Hotel Boycotted Over Brunei's Sharia Penal Code|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/05/06/beverly-hills-hotel-boycott-brunei_n_5271996.html|accessdate=1 December 2014|work=Huffington Post|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=6 May 2014}}</ref> This part of the law was to come into effect in 2016,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thediplomat.com/2015/05/the-implications-of-bruneis-sharia-law/|title=The Implications of Brunei’s Sharia Law|last=Ozanick|first=Bill|work=The Diplomat|date=May 21, 2015|access-date=2017-06-25|language=en-US}}</ref> although it's now expected to come into effect in 2018. In 2016, a 22 year old women was sentenced to seven years in prison for obtaining an abortion using the [[Medical abortion|abortion pill]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brudirect.com/news.php?id=14492|title=Youth in Abortion Case Set for Time in Jail, fine|last=|first=|date=|website=www.brudirect.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-25}}</ref>
== Clothing norms == The Muslim women of Brunei wear traditional head cover known as the ''[[tudong]]'',<ref name=EC/> also spelled as ''tudung''.
== Gender roles == In recent years, Bruneian women have started to assume "positions of responsibility" in the [[Government of Brunei]]. They are able to take jobs in the [[armed forces of Brunei]]; however they are not allowed to serve while in combat situations.<ref name=EC/>
